item.title: Alien abduction entities
item.description:
Alien Abduction Entities üîó

This article discusses the beings alleged to be responsible for alien abductions, focusing on their reported characteristics, motivations, and the plausibility of these claims. It acknowledges the ongoing debate surrounding the phenomenon, with scientists and mental health professionals largely attributing such experiences to psychological and environmental factors rather than literal events.

Alleged Motivations üîó

This section explores the purported reasons behind alien abductions, as claimed by experiencers. Dr. John G. Miller is mentioned, noting that abductees often report entities claiming a “right” to perform invasive procedures. Author and UFOlogist Jenny Randles’ study is highlighted, which analyzed motivations given by abductors in about 50 abduction claims. Randles found a common narrative of long-term surveillance and interaction, where entities target individuals for unique qualities, repeatedly abducting them to implant information that will be activated later, potentially to assist humanity during major Earth changes. Different entity types, such as “Nordics” and “Grays,” are said to have varying motivations.

Types üîó

This section categorizes the different types of entities reported in alien abduction claims. It presents two tables summarizing these types based on different studies. The first table, based on a survey of 203 pre-1985 abduction claims, lists types such as “Short Humanoids,” “Average (Human) Height Humanoids,” “Tall Humanoids,” “Mummy-like,” “Miscellaneous Humanoids,” “Human-like,” and “Non-human.” The second table, based on Claudier Covo’s Brazilian Alien Typology from 138 alleged abductions, categorizes entities as Alpha, Beta, Gamma, Delta, Omega, and Sigma based on their height and form. The section also mentions “Mantid aliens,” described by abductees as often being in charge of Grays.

Reported Technology üîó

This section details the technology allegedly used by alien abduction entities. It mentions reports of levitation, entities passing through walls, and other advanced capabilities. It also references ufologists’ books that describe these technologies without providing detailed hypotheses about their feasibility.

Weapon üîó

This subsection focuses on a specific weapon allegedly used by Grey aliens, as described in Nick Pope’s book The Uninvited. The weapon is described as a black, cylindrical device, similar in size to a pencil, with a bluish light on one end. It is supposedly used to subdue combative abductees by numbing their will, resembling a Star Trek phaser.

Medical üîó

This subsection describes a medical device reported by Linda Moulton Howe, a pencil-sized cylindrical device with a light on one end, independently reported in at least two alleged abductions. The device is said to function like a surgical scalpel, opening the body bloodlessly and in “slow motion,” described by one claimant as “opening the body with sound.”

Plausibility and Veracity üîó

This section examines the credibility of alien abduction claims, considering factors that might influence abductor descriptions.

Hypnosis as an Influence on Abductor Descriptions üîó

This subsection discusses the impact of hypnosis on the descriptions of abducting beings. Folklorist and abduction researcher Thomas E. Bullard notes that while skeptics might expect Hollywood influence to dominate descriptions, the abduction literature doesn’t reflect this. Bullard also observes that hypnosis as a memory retrieval method seems to affect descriptions, with hypnotically assisted recall more likely to produce descriptions of “standard” Grey humanoids, while cases without hypnosis include more variety. Bullard poses the question of whether hypnosis shapes memories or reveals the true appearance of the beings.

Geography and Culture as Influences on Abductor Descriptions üîó

This subsection explores how cultural and geographic factors influence abduction reports. Robert Sheaffer observes that the types of aliens reported vary by region, with large-headed gray aliens predominating in North America, tall, blond, Nordic aliens in Britain, and more bizarre creatures in South America. The section also notes that the “grey alien” paradigm is primarily associated with North America since the 1980s, while researchers like Kevin D. Randle have documented a vast variety of alleged creatures reported worldwide. Common elements in abduction descriptions vary by region and local culture, with only a few elements being consistent worldwide, such as otherworldly sensations, mind control, repressed memories, and sexual experiences, which are also common in stories of encounters with faeries, demons, and other magical creatures. In Brazil, links exist between the abduction phenomenon and spiritist traditions, with reports of spiritual space surgeons sharing common imagery with alien abductions but perceived as pleasant and spiritual rather than terrifying.

Science Fiction as an Influence üîó

This subsection considers the potential influence of science fiction on abduction claims. Sheaffer notes similarities between aliens depicted in early science fiction films, such as Invaders From Mars, and those reported in abduction accounts. Commonalities exist in the appearances, behavior, technology, and societies of fictional and allegedly real abductors. The “abduction narrative” was established in fictional form by 1930 in a Buck Rogers comic strip. However, Bullard does not see evidence for influence on abduction claimants from science fiction sources.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_abduction_entities

item.title: Alien abduction
item.description:
Alien Abduction üîó

Alien abduction, also known as abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction, is the subjective experience of individuals reporting being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation. Those who claim to have been abducted are referred to as “abductees” or “experiencers.” The prevailing scientific and mental health perspective attributes these experiences to factors like suggestibility, sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology. Skeptics draw parallels between alien descriptions and science fiction films like Invaders From Mars (1953).

Typical claims involve forced medical examinations, particularly focusing on reproductive systems. Some abductees report warnings about environmental abuses and nuclear weapons, or involvement in interspecies breeding. The narratives often vary based on the abductee’s cultural background. UFOs, alien abduction, and mind control are sometimes integrated into radical political apocalyptic and millenarian narratives.

Reports are global, but most common in English-speaking countries, especially the United States. The Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1961 was the first widely publicized case. UFO abduction claims have declined since the mid-1970s, possibly due to the increased availability of camera phones.

Overview üîó

Mainstream scientists generally dismiss claims of literal alien abduction. John E. Mack, a psychiatrist who gave credence to such claims, noted that most abductees are sane individuals, with psychopathology present in only some cases. Detailed abduction reports have led to the development of a subculture with support groups and a mythos explaining the roles, origins, and motivations of various alien types (Greys, Reptilians, Nordics, etc.). Some claimants conduct independent research and attribute the lack of wider awareness to extraterrestrial or governmental cover-ups.

History üîó

Paleo-abductions üîó

Before the widespread attention to “alien abduction” in the 1960s, some older stories have been speculated as possible cases, termed “paleo-abductions” by UFO researcher Jerome Clark.

  • In 1896, Colonel H. G. Shaw claimed he and a friend were harassed by tall, slender humanoids who tried to kidnap them.
  • In 1953, an article in Man to Man Magazine questioned whether humans were being captured by flying saucers for zoological specimens or vivisection.
  • In 1955, Harold T. Wilkins’s Flying Saucers Uncensored reported the mysterious disappearance of Karl Hunrath and Wilbur Wilkinson, who had claimed contact with aliens, speculating they were victims of abduction by flying saucers.

Two landmark cases üîó

The Ant√¥nio Vilas-Boas case in Brazil in the mid-1950s was an early claim, but the Betty and Barney Hill abduction case of 1961 generated widespread publicity, including a 1975 television film. The Hill incident was a prototypical case, possibly the first to describe beings later known as the Greys and explicitly identify an extraterrestrial origin.

These cases established a template for later abductees and researchers. Purported abductions were cited contemporaneously at least as early as 1954.

Later developments üîó

R. Leo Sprinkle, a University of Wyoming psychologist, became interested in the abduction phenomenon in the 1960s and became convinced of its actuality. He was perhaps the first to suggest a link between abductions and cattle mutilation. Eventually, Sprinkle came to believe that he had been abducted by aliens in his youth; he was forced from his job in 1989. Budd Hopkins became interested in abduction reports in the 1970s and used hypnosis to extract more details, becoming a figurehead of the abductee subculture.

The 1980s brought mainstream attention to the subject through works by Hopkins, Whitley Strieber, David M. Jacobs, and John E. Mack. Folklorist Thomas E. Bullard’s comparative analysis of nearly 300 alleged abductees was also published.

Accounts of alien abduction became a prominent aspect of ufology. Jacobs and Hopkins argued that alien abduction was far more common than earlier suspected, estimating that tens of thousands (or more) North Americans had been taken by unexplained beings.

Jacobs and Hopkins argued that aliens were attempting to create human‚Äìalien hybrids, the most advanced stage of which in the “human hybridization program” are known as hubrids, though the motives for this effort were unknown.

Descriptions of alien encounters as researched and presented by Hopkins, Jacobs and Mack were similar, with slight differences in each researcher’s emphasis.

According to Boston Globe writer Linda Rodriguez McRobbie, abduction stories have declined in mainstream media. Skeptic Michael Shermer noted that “the camera-phone age is increasing the burden of evidence on experiencers”.

John E. Mack üîó

Harvard psychiatry professor John E. Mack believed in the credibility of alien abduction claims. Niall Boyce writing in The Lancet called him “a well-meaning man uncritically elaborating on tales of alien abduction, and potentially both cementing and constructing false memories”. Boyce observed that Mack’s work in hypnotic regression of claimants helped spread the Grey aliens meme into the culture.

Mack became interested in claims of alien abduction in the late 1980s, interviewing over 800 people and eventually writing two books on the subject. Due to Mack’s belief and subsequent promotion of the claims of those he interviewed, his professional reputation suffered, prompting Harvard to review his position in 1994. He retained tenure, but “was not taken seriously by his colleagues anymore‚Äù.

Abductees üîó

The precise number of alleged abductees is uncertain. One of the earliest studies of abductions found 1,700 claimants, while contested surveys argued that 5‚Äì6 percent of the general population allege to have been abducted.

Demographics üîó

Although abduction and other UFO-related reports are usually made by adults, sometimes young children report similar experiences. These child-reports often feature very specific details in common with reports of abduction made by adults, including the circumstances, narrative, entities and aftermaths of the alleged occurrences. Often, these young abductees have family members who have reported having abduction experiences. Family involvement in the military, or a residence near a military base is also common among child abduction claimants.

Mental health üîó

Some studies show that abductees have psychological characteristics that render their testimony suspect, while others show that “as a group, abduction experients are not different from the general population in term of psychopathology prevalence”. Elizabeth Slater conducted a blind study of nine abduction claimants and found them to be prone to “mildly paranoid thinking”, nightmares and having a weak sexual identity, while Richard McNally of Harvard Medical School concluded in a similar study of 10 abductees that “none of them was suffering from any sort of psychiatric illness.”

Political conspiracy theories üîó

Political scientist Michael Barkun highlighted links between radical politics and conspiracy theories involving UFOs, alien visitation, environmental pollution, hidden groups, government and world takeover. He observed the rise of a form of eclectic and apocalyptic millenarism which he termed “improvisional millenarism”. UFO and abduction stories can often be part of stigmatized or suppressed knowledge narratives, where alleged orthodoxy is claimed to be maintained in error for nefarious purposes and to keep society in ignorance. UFO and alien-related conspiracy theories emerged in far-right politics from the 1980s onwards.

According to Barkun, in popular culture, TV shows like The X-Files and its motion picture not only included aliens as part of coverup conspiracies, with militias and black helicopters but also featured demonization of FEMA, a common target of conspiracy theorists and millenarian scenarios. One conspiracy theory alleges that FEMA plans to incarcerate “patriots” suddenly in concentration camps during a disaster. Political scientist Jodi Dean noted that the stigma of alien abduction stories is seductive to dismiss “consensus reality” in favor of deviant alternative realities.

Self-described abduction victims often join self-help communities of victims and may resort to questionable regression therapy, similarly to other self-reported victims of child sexual abuse or satanic ritual abuse. Some espouse conspiracy theories of sophisticated technological mind control, including the use of implants, to force them to serve an alleged New World Order, or for the purposes of the antichrist, considering it important to warn the world of such imminent danger.

Abduction narrative üîó

Various researchers have noted common points in report narratives. According to CUFOS’s definition of abductee, the person must have been taken against their will by apparent non-human beings, taken to a special place perceived as extraterrestrial or to be a spaceship. They then must experience being subjected to an examination or to engage in some form of communication with the beings (or both). Communication may be perceived as telepathic rather than verbal. The memory of the experience may be conscious or “recovered” through means like hypnosis.

Although different cases vary in detail (sometimes significantly), some UFO researchers, such as folklorist Thomas E. Bullard argue that there is a broad, fairly consistent sequence and description of events that make up the typical “close encounter of the fourth kind” (a popular but unofficial designation building on J. Allen Hynek’s classifications). Though the features outlined below are often reported, there is some disagreement as to exactly how often they actually occur.

Bullard argues most abduction accounts feature the following events. They generally follow the sequence noted below, though not all abductions feature all the events:

  1. Capture. The abduct

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_abduction

item.title: Alien Autopsy (1995 television film)
item.description:
Alien Autopsy (1995 television film) üîó

This article discusses the 1995 pseudo-documentary Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, which featured footage purporting to show an alien autopsy conducted after the Roswell incident. The program, hosted by Jonathan Frakes, aired on Fox and other networks worldwide, sparking intense debate before being thoroughly debunked as a hoax.

Production üîó

This section details the production of the Alien Autopsy footage. Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield admitted to creating the footage in a 2006 documentary. The simulated autopsy was filmed in a London living room using fabricated alien bodies constructed by artist John Humphreys. The alien bodies were made of plaster casts filled with offal, sheep brains, and raspberry jam. Alien artifacts were also created by Humphreys. A homeless man was paid to pose as the original cameraman.

In popular culture üîó

This section outlines how Alien Autopsy was received and referenced in popular culture. The program was widely derided, including being satirized in The X-Files. Fox later aired a special debunking the footage. A fictionalized version of the creation and release of the footage was retold in the comedy film Alien Autopsy (2006).

References üîó

This section lists the various sources used to support the information presented in the article. These include books, news articles, and documentaries.

Further reading üîó

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers who want to learn more about the Alien Autopsy film and the surrounding controversy.

External links üîó

This section provides links to external websites related to the Alien Autopsy film, including an article by Ray Santilli and links to the film’s IMDb page and a YouTube video.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_(1995_film)

item.title: Cattle mutilation
item.description:
Cattle Mutilation üîó

Cattle mutilation refers to the killing and mutilation of cattle (and other animals) under unusual and often bloodless circumstances. The phenomenon is often linked to paranormal or supernatural explanations, including cults, government agencies, cryptids like the chupacabra, and extraterrestrials. The article notes that similar mutilations have been observed in other livestock and wild animals, with specific body parts often removed. Two independent federal investigations in the United States have been conducted on the topic.

Early History üîó

The earliest documented outbreak of unexplained livestock deaths occurred in England in 1606. Later, Charles Fort collected accounts of cattle mutilations in England during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

The “Snippy” Horse Death of 1967 üîó

This section focuses on the 1967 case of a horse named “Snippy” found mutilated in Alamosa, Colorado. The Pueblo Chieftain published a story about the incident, which gained national attention and sparked speculation about extraterrestrial involvement. Agnes King and her son Harry found the horse’s body, noting the precise cuts and lack of blood. Wadsworth Ayer investigated for the Condon Committee and concluded there was no evidence of abnormal causes. Sheriff Ben Phillips suggested a lightning strike as the cause.

Cattle Mutilations 1973‚Äì1980 üîó

This section covers a wave of cattle mutilations reported in Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and New Mexico during the 1970s. It mentions reports of unidentified helicopters involved in cattle rustling in Iowa and Missouri in 1973.

1973 Kansas Wave üîó

In June 1973, Cloud County sheriff Fred Modlin warned the public about suspicious phone calls from someone posing as a USDA official. Several butchered cows were found on farms in the area, with right ears removed. Local press speculated about a “Mad Dog” or “phantom” butcher. By December, law enforcement reported investigating 40 mutilations across Kansas and Nebraska. State Senator Ross Doyen also reported a mutilation on his ranch. The Kansas Brand Commissioner’s office attributed most deaths to natural causes, a conclusion disputed by Modlin.

1974 Nebraska Wave üîó

Reports of mutilations resumed in April 1974 in Nebraska. The North American Newspaper Alliance reported on the 1973 mutilations and helicopter sightings. Mutilations were reported in Iowa and Nebraska counties. In Custer County, there were reports of helicopter sightings and armed patrols. An unidentified helicopter was spotted shining a spotlight above a field where a mutilated cow was later found near Agnew, Nebraska. Knox County Sheriff Herbert Thompson reported armed civilian patrols. The Kansas Bureau of Investigation leaned toward predators as the cause. State Sen. John Decamp called for a coordinated investigation. By late August, 25 mutilations were reported across five Nebraska counties. Authorities cautioned the public against shooting at aircraft. A meeting of law enforcement officials from 24 counties was held to discuss the mutilations.

1975 Colorado üîó

The Colorado Associated Press voted the mutilations as the state’s top story in 1975. Senator Floyd K. Haskell contacted the FBI, claiming 130 mutilations in Colorado and reports across nine states. A 1979 FBI report estimated 8,000 mutilations in Colorado, causing $1 million in damages. Donald E. Flickinger of the Michigan ATF investigated possible links to a “Hell-oriented biker gang.” The Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside.

1976 Dulce, New Mexico üîó

In June 1976, Dulce rancher Manuel Gomez reported a mutilation to Officer Gabe Valdez of the New Mexico State Patrol.

1979 Public Meeting üîó

In April 1979, U.S. Attorney R. E. Thompson and US Senator Harrison Schmidt held a public meeting about cattle mutilations. Paul Bennewitz reported seeing unidentified lights over Kirtland Air Force Base. Gabe Valdez reported finding tranquilizers in the remains of a mutilated bull. In June 1981, investigators found a mutilated cow at the Gomez ranch with radar chaff nearby.

Later Incidents üîó

Many cases of mutilation have been reported worldwide since 1967, especially in the Americas and Australia. In South America, an estimated 3,500 incidents have occurred since 2002.

Characteristics üîó

Unusual cattle deaths are characterized by the absence of sex organs, udders, tongues, anus, rectum, and sometimes ears or eyes. Cuts are described as “clean” and “surgical.” Some animals are reported to have been drained of blood with no sign of blood in the area. Nearly 90 percent of mutilated cattle are between four and five years old. Strange marks or imprints near the site have been found.

Laboratory Reports üîó

Laboratory reports on some mutilated animals have shown unusual levels of vitamins or minerals and the presence of chemicals not normally found in animals. In a case documented by New Mexico police and the FBI involving a bull belonging to Manuel Gomez of Dulce, New Mexico, the animal displayed classic mutilation signs. The animal’s heart, bone, and muscle samples were sent to the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, while liver samples were sent to private laboratories. The liver was found to be completely devoid of copper and to contain high levels of zinc, potassium, and phosphorus. Blood samples did not clot, and the hide was unusually brittle.

Helicopter Sightings üîó

In July 1974, two unregistered helicopters reportedly opened fire on Robert Smith Jr. in Honey Creek, Iowa. In August 1974, residents reported seeing unidentified helicopters shining spotlights into fields where mutilated cows were later found. By 1975, some ranchers formed armed vigilante groups. In 1976, two Cache County, Utah, police officers reportedly confronted men in an unmarked U.S. Army helicopter. In April 1979, three police officers in Dulce, New Mexico, reported a mysterious aircraft resembling a U.S. military helicopter.

Official Investigations üîó

Federal authorities launched a comprehensive investigation of the mutilation phenomenon.

Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms üîó

In January 1975, the ATF launched an investigation headed by Agent Donald Flickinger to investigate possible connections between cults and cattle mutilation. Flickinger recorded unusual incidents but found insufficient evidence of cult involvement.

Colorado Bureau of Investigation üîó

In May 1975, the Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. 19 animals underwent necropsies at Colorado State University, but no conclusive results emerged.

New Mexico State Police üîó

In June 1976, the New Mexico State Police began an investigation headed by Officer Gabe Valdez. Valdez solicited assistance from retired Sandia National Laboratories scientist Howard Burgess. The investigation reported finding evidence that some mutilated animals had been tranquilized and treated with an anti-coagulant.

Rommel Investigation üîó

Beginning in May 1979, an investigation was funded by a grant from the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration and headed by retired FBI agent Kenneth Rommel. Rommel’s report concluded that the mutilations were predominantly the result of natural predation, but some cases contained anomalies that could not be accounted for.

Conventional Explanations üîó

There are several potential explanations for cattle mutilations, ranging from death by natural causes to purposeful acts by unknown individuals.

Natural Causes üîó

Missing or mutilated body parts are explained as the actions of scavengers, parasites, and dehydration. Absence of blood is explained as blood pooling or consumption by insects. Surgical incisions are explained as tears in the skin due to bloating or dehydration.

Animal Cruelty, Pranks, and Hoaxes üîó

Cattle mutilations are hypothesized to be the result of predation and other natural processes, and those with anomalies are the work of humans who derive pleasure from mutilating animals.

Covert Monitoring of Threats to Public Health üîó

Cattle mutilations might be the result of covert research into emerging cattle diseases. Colm Kelleher argues that the mutilations are a clandestine U.S. government effort to track the spread of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (“mad cow disease”). Greg Valdez concludes that mutilations were a government testing program looking at the after-effects of radiation from 1967’s Project Gasbuggy.

Secret Weapons Testing üîó

The government was testing cattle parts to develop biological weapons. In March 1968, 6,000 sheep were killed as part of chemical weapons testing.

Other Explanations üîó

Fringe explanations for the mutilation have blamed satanic cults, aliens, or even mythical monsters.

Satanic Cults üîó

Cattle mutilations are the result of cult activity. However, the FBI and the ATF were unable to find appropriate evidence to substantiate that the animals had been the victims of any form of ritual sacrifice or organized mutilation effort.

Aliens üîó

Press had linked reports of unidentified aircraft to UFOs and flying saucers. In 1974, farmers in Nebraska claimed to witness UFOs on the nights their cattle were harmed. In 1980, journalist Linda Moulton Howe claimed the mutilations were linked to UFOs and aliens. The 2013 documentary Mirage Men suggests there was conspiracy by the U.S. military to fabricate UFO folklore. Paul Bennewitz was introduced to highway patrol officer Gabe Valdez at a public meeting about the ongoing cattle mutilations.

Mythic Monsters üîó

Folklore

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cattle_mutilation

item.title: UFO conspiracy theories
item.description:
UFO Conspiracy Theories üîó

This article discusses various conspiracy theories surrounding Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs), focusing on the alleged suppression of evidence by governments, particularly the United States government, regarding extraterrestrial intelligence or advanced technology derived from alien sources. It also touches upon claims of government cooperation with extraterrestrials and the allowance of events like cattle mutilation and alien abduction.

Overview üîó

This section introduces the historical context of UFO conspiracy theories, tracing their origins to pulp science fiction and “lost continent” myths. It mentions Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting and the subsequent surge in UFO reports. Key figures like Donald Keyhoe, who popularized the idea of a government cover-up, and the introduction of the “Men in Black” concept are highlighted. The section also covers the evolution of these theories, linking them to events like the Kennedy assassination and dramatizations in popular culture, such as the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind. It notes the shift from theories about benevolent “space brothers” to darker narratives involving malevolent aliens and government cabals. The section concludes by mentioning the renewed interest in UFO conspiracy theories following Leslie Kean’s reporting on a 21st-century Pentagon UFO program.

Mainstream Views üîó

This section presents the mainstream scientific perspective on UFOs, emphasizing that while unusual sightings have been reported throughout history, there is no confirmed evidence to support claims of extraterrestrial origins. It mentions government investigations like Project Blue Book and Project Condign, as well as skeptical organizations like the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry, which offer prosaic explanations for UFO sightings, such as natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, and hoaxes. The section also touches upon the psychosocial explanations for UFO beliefs, viewing them as modern folklore and mythology. Benjamin Radford’s argument about the unlikelihood of a decades-long, international government cover-up is also presented.

Notable Proponents üîó

This section identifies key individuals who have promoted UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions Donald Keyhoe, Jacque Vallee, J. Allen Hynek, and Stanton Friedman as prominent figures from the 1950s to the 1970s. It also notes that some proponents, like Richard Shaver and Paul Bennewitz, had histories of psychiatric issues, while others, like Gray Barker and Bill Moore, confessed to hoaxes or lies. The section lists individuals like Barry Goldwater, Lord Hill-Norton, Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, Gordon Cooper, and Edgar Mitchell, who have suggested that UFO evidence is being suppressed. 21st-century proponents such as Paul Hellyer, Garry Nolan, Haim Eshed, Jim Semivan, Harold E. Puthoff, Tom DeLonge, Luis Elizondo, and David Grusch are also mentioned.

In Popular Fiction üîó

This section explores the presence of UFO conspiracy theories in various works of popular fiction. It mentions films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Easy Rider, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Total Recall, Independence Day, and Men in Black, as well as TV shows like The X-Files, Dark Skies, and Stargate. The section also notes John Glenn’s appearance on Frasier, where he confessed to a fictional UFO cover-up. The Sidney Sheldon novel The Doomsday Conspiracy and the series American Horror Story: Double Feature are also mentioned.

In Religion üîó

This section examines the intersection of UFO conspiracy theories and new religious movements. It identifies groups like the Nation of Islam, Scientology, and Heaven’s Gate as examples. The section also touches upon Mormon cosmology and its teachings about inhabited planets. It mentions the Theosophical backgrounds of early “contactees” like Meade Layne, George Adamski, and George Hunt Williamson, as well as Guy Warren Ballard, founder of the “I AM” Activity. The section also discusses the Nation of Islam’s concept of “The Mother Plane,” L. Ron Hubbard’s teachings about Xenu, and the Ra√´lism movement. It concludes by mentioning the Heaven’s Gate suicides and the Order of the Solar Temple mass deaths.

Chronology of UFO Conspiracy Theories üîó

This section provides a detailed timeline of the development of UFO conspiracy theories, starting with Raymond Palmer’s pulp magazine in the 1940s.

1940s Origin in Raymond Palmer’s Pulp Magazine üîó

This subsection focuses on the role of Raymond Palmer and his Amazing Stories magazine in the emergence of UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions Palmer’s publication of reports of strange craft and his hiring of Kenneth Arnold to investigate a flying disc report. The subsection also highlights Palmer’s promotion of the idea that the truth behind the discs was being covered up.

Spaceships of “The Shaver Mystery” üîó

This subsection discusses the “Shaver Mystery” stories published in Amazing Stories, based on the writings of Richard Shaver, who claimed to be in telepathic communication with a secret underground race. It notes Shaver’s history of psychiatric problems and the blurring of fact and fiction in his stories. The subsection also mentions Palmer’s argument that “responsible parties in world governments” were aware of spaceships visiting Earth.

Kenneth Arnold Ignites Flying Disc Craze üîó

This subsection covers the beginning of the flying disc craze with Kenneth Arnold’s sighting and the subsequent surge in UFO reports. It mentions the Roswell incident and the Army’s initial press release about recovering a “flying disc.” The subsection also discusses Palmer’s contact with Arnold and their investigation of Fred Crisman’s claims near Maury Island, Washington.

Aftermath üîó

This subsection describes the aftermath of the 1947 flying disc craze, including Palmer’s argument that the flap was proof of Richard Sharpe Shaver’s claims. It quotes Shaver’s prediction that the truth behind the discs would never be disclosed to the common people. The subsection also mentions Shaver’s devotion to “rock books” and Palmer’s admission that Shaver had spent time in a mental institution. It concludes by noting Palmer’s later linking of flying saucers, the Shaver Mystery, the Kennedy assassination, Watergate, and Fred Crisman.

National Coverage in the 1950s üîó

This section details the increased governmental and civilian investigative efforts and reports of public disinformation and suppression of evidence during the 1950s.

Aztec “Alien Bodies” Hoax üîó

This subsection focuses on the first “alien bodies” conspiracy theory, which emerged in 1949 with Frank Scully’s columns in Variety. It mentions Scully’s claims that dead extraterrestrial beings were recovered from a flying saucer crash and his book Behind the Flying Saucers. The subsection also notes the later revelation that Scully had been the victim of confidence artists and the exposure of the hoax by True magazine.

Air Force Accounts üîó

This subsection discusses the Air Force’s handling of UFO reports, including General John Samford’s 1952 press conference and the Robertson Panel’s recommendation for a public education campaign. It mentions Al Chop’s role as the press spokesman for Project Bluebook and the film Unidentified Flying Objects: The True Story of Flying Saucers. The subsection also covers Edward J. Ruppelt’s book The Report on Unidentified Flying Objects and its criticism of the Air Force’s handling of UFO investigations.

“Philadelphia Experiment” Hoax üîó

This subsection covers the “Philadelphia Experiment” hoax, which emerged with Morris K. Jessup’s book The Case for the UFO and the letters he received from “Carlos Miguel Allende.” It mentions the tale of a navy ship made invisible and teleporting from Philadelphia to Norfolk, Virginia. The subsection also discusses the annotated copy of Jessup’s book and his death by suicide.

‘Men in Black’ Legends üîó

This subsection focuses on the emergence of the “Men in Black” legend with Gray Barker’s book They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers. It mentions the speculation that the men in black are government agents who harass and threaten UFO witnesses. The subsection also notes the possibility that government agencies did attempt to discourage public interest in UFOs during the 1950s.

1960-70s: Growing Distrust in Government üîó

This section discusses the era of government skepticism that began in the 1960s, following events like the assassination of John F. Kennedy, the Pentagon Papers, and the Watergate scandal.

Fred Crisman and JFK Conspiracy Theories üîó

This subsection covers the linking of Fred Crisman to the Kennedy assassination and a supposed UFO cover-up. It mentions Jim Garrison’s prosecution of Clay Shaw and Crisman’s subpoena and testimony. The subsection also notes the House Select Committee on Assassinations’ consideration of Crisman as one of the “three tramps.”

“Cosmic Watergate” üîó

This subsection discusses the concept of a “Cosmic Watergate,” referring to a supposed government cover-up of UFO information. It mentions the film 2001: A Space Odyssey and its themes of government conspiracy. The subsection also covers J. Allen Hynek’s accusations that Bluebook was “a Cosmic Watergate” and Jimmy Carter’s pledge to release UFO information if elected.

Alien Bodies at “Hangar 18” üîó

This subsection focuses on the legends of alien bodies being stored at a mythical “Hangar 18” at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. It mentions Robert Spencer Carr’s allegation that alien bodies recovered from the Aztec crash were stored in “H

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_conspiracy_theories

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens üîó

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulans, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are purported extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 popularized the image of Grey aliens. These beings have become an archetypal image of extraterrestrial life and a popular trope in science fiction.

Description üîó

Appearance üîó

Greys are generally described as diminutive humanoid beings with grey skin and reduced or absent external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. They have disproportionately large heads, no hair, and small openings for ears, nostrils, and mouths. Their most striking feature is their large, opaque, black eyes. They are often described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli üîó

The connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system originated with Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a star map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed the aliens showed her a map of their home system and nearby stars. Fish created a model based on Hill’s drawing and identified the aliens’ home as Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History üîó

Origins üîó

Descriptions of beings similar to Grey aliens predate claims of encounters. H.G. Wells described future humans with large heads and lacking mouths, noses, or hair in his 1893 article “The Man of the Year Million” and his 1895 novel The Time Machine. In 1917, Aleister Crowley described a meeting with a “preternatural entity” named Lam, resembling a modern Grey. In 1933, Swedish novelist Gustav Sandgren (Gabriel Linde) described aliens with grey clothes, bald heads, and large eyes in his science fiction novel The Unknown Danger.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction üîó

The archetype became famous in 1965 with newspaper reports of the Betty and Barney Hill abduction. The Hills claimed that in 1961, grey-skinned humanoid aliens abducted them and took them aboard a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer suggested Barney’s memories might have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield,” which aired shortly before Barney’s first hypnotic session and featured an alien with large eyes. Carl Sagan echoed this suspicion, citing Invaders from Mars as another potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore üîó

After the Hill’s encounter, Greys became integral to ufology and extraterrestrial folklore, especially in the United States, where they account for 73% of reported alien encounters. During the early 1980s, Greys were linked to the alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. In 1987, Whitley Strieber published Communion, a non-fiction book describing his alleged encounters with Greys, which became a bestseller and was adapted into a film. In 1988, Jimmy Guieu described “the little greys” on French television, popularizing the term les Petits-Gris.

Greys have since become the subject of many conspiracy theories, with some theorists believing they are part of a government disinformation campaign or products of mind-control experiments. During the 1990s, popular culture increasingly linked Greys to military-industrial complex and New World Order conspiracy theories. In 1995, Ray Santilli claimed to have obtained film footage of an autopsy of a “real” Grey recovered from Roswell, though he later admitted it was a “reconstruction.”

Analysis üîó

In close encounter claims and ufology üîó

Greys are often involved in alien abduction claims, accounting for a significant percentage of reports in Australia, the United States, continental Europe, and the United Kingdom. These reports often describe traumatic experiences, similar to human abduction or sexual assault. The eyes are a focal point in these claims, with abductees describing Greys staring into their eyes to induce hallucinogenic states or provoke emotions.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence üîó

Neurologist Steven Novella proposes that Grey aliens are a product of the human imagination, with their features representing traits associated with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” üîó

Frederick V. Malmstrom suggests that Greys are residual memories of early childhood development, reconstructing the face of a Grey through transformation of a mother’s face.

Evolutionary implausibility üîó

Biologist Jack Cohen argues that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be a credible representation of an alien from a different environment.

Other hypotheses üîó

The interdimensional, cryptoterrestrial, and time-traveler hypotheses attempt to provide alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of these alleged beings.

In popular culture üîó

Grey aliens have become a common depiction of extraterrestrials in fiction, supplanting the “little green men.” They have appeared in films and television shows like Ultraman, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Babylon 5, and Stargate. During the 1990s, plotlines linking Greys to conspiracy theories became common, as seen in The X-Files. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The film Paul attributes the Greys’ presence in pop culture to the US government deliberately inserting their image into mainstream media. The 2013 film Dark Skies features child abduction by Greys. Greys also appear in the Syfy series Resident Alien and the 2023 game Greyhill Incident.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey_alien

item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Nordic Aliens üîó

In ufology, “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites” are terms used to describe alleged humanoid extraterrestrial races from the Pleiades star cluster. These beings are said to resemble Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans, with features like tall stature (6-7 ft), blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some reports describe their skin tone as pale blue/grey or pastel purple.

History üîó

Cultural historian David J. Skal suggests that early stories of Nordic aliens may have been inspired by the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still. Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” noting that believers often associate Nordic aliens with spiritual growth and protection.

In ufology, Nordic aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned about Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal, watchful, smiling, affectionate, and youthful.

During the 1950s, many people, especially in Europe, claimed encounters with these beings. However, such claims became less common in later decades, as the grey alien became more prevalent in extraterrestrial encounter accounts.

Publications by Those Claiming to Have Been Contacted üîó

Several books claim personal contact with Nordic aliens, including:

  • Flying Saucers Have Landed by Desmond Leslie and George Adamski
  • Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski
  • From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger
  • The Walton Experience by Travis Walton
  • Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites)

The UFO religion Universe People also publishes “Talks with Teachings from my Cosmic Friends” detailing interactions with extraterrestrials.

See Also üîó

This section lists related topics, including:

  • Space Brothers
  • Truman Bethurum
  • Elizabeth Klarer
  • Billy Meier
  • Linda Moulton Howe
  • List of alleged extraterrestrial beings
  • Star people (New Age)
  • Arcturians (New Age)
  • UFOs
  • UFO religion

References üîó

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, academic papers, and online resources.

External Links üîó

This section provides a link to Wikimedia Commons for media related to Nordic aliens.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordic_aliens

item.title: White Orb Watches Family BBQ Over Lakeland, Florida
item.description:
An eyewitness at a family BBQ were enjoying the day when someone pointed out a white orb in the sky above. Then others came and they noticed it stayed over them as if it were watching them and recording the humans reactions to what they were seeing. You see, aliens love knowledge, like humans like money, knowledge is everything to them. The smaller orb drones are sent out from a mother drone and months later gathered after the orbs have recorded information about anything and everything they saw.

item.title: Alien Hive
item.description:
Alien Hive üîó

Alien Hive is a puzzle video game developed and published by Malaysia-based studio Appxplore in March 2013. It is available on iOS, Android, and Windows Phone platforms. The game combines match-three and sliding puzzle mechanics.

Gameplay üîó

The gameplay involves swiping tiles to match eggs and aliens, with the goal of hatching, breeding, and evolving them into the Supreme Alien. Players aim to build the ultimate alien hive by matching resource tiles while avoiding Naughty Bots. Power-ups can be crafted to eliminate these troublemakers, and players are encouraged to minimize their moves. As players progress, they encounter more aliens and uncover their mysteries.

Magic Fruit, collected by merging seeds into saplings, is key to evolving Supreme Aliens. These fruits allow merging of similar-level items using only two of a kind instead of three. Evolved Supreme Aliens can be activated using gold to provide special bonuses in future games.

In App Purchase üîó

Alien Hive incorporates microtransactions, where real money can be exchanged for in-game gold to purchase consumable items. This aspect of the game has faced criticism, with one review suggesting that microtransactions are almost essential.

Reception üîó

Alien Hive received an average score of 70 out of 100 based on reviews aggregated by Metacritic.

By 2015, the game had achieved over 3 million downloads across all platforms.

References üîó

This section lists the references cited in the article, including links to sources such as the Appxplore website, the Google Play Store, My Filing Cabinet, GameZEBO, Metacritic, and Vulcan Post. These links provide verification and further information about the game’s details, reviews, and achievements.

External links üîó

This section provides a link to the official website of Alien Hive.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Hive

item.title: Extraterrestrial life
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Life üîó

Extraterrestrial life, also known as alien life, refers to life that originates from a world other than Earth. While no such life has been conclusively detected, it could range from simple prokaryotes to intelligent beings and civilizations. The study of extraterrestrial life falls under the domain of astrobiology.

Context üîó

This section provides a framework for understanding the topic of life in the universe. It outlines the conditions necessary for life to arise, starting from the Big Bang and the formation of elements like carbon and oxygen through stellar fusion. It touches on the concepts of planetary systems, habitable zones, and the vast distances involved in studying extraterrestrial life. The section also mentions the role of abiogenesis and panspermia in the origin and spread of life.

Likelihood of Existence üîó

This section delves into the debate about whether life in the cosmos is common or rare. It presents the argument for ubiquitous extraterrestrial life, based on the size and age of the universe, the abundance of life’s building blocks, and the universality of physical laws. Key figures like Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking are mentioned as proponents of this view. The opposing Rare Earth hypothesis, which posits that a unique combination of factors makes Earth exceptionally suited for life, is also discussed. The Drake equation, developed by Frank Drake, is introduced as a probabilistic tool for estimating the number of communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way, while acknowledging its controversial and speculative nature. The Fermi paradox, the apparent contradiction between the high probability of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of evidence for them, is also mentioned.

Biochemical Basis üîó

This section explores the potential biochemical foundations of extraterrestrial life. It acknowledges that life could range from microorganisms to intelligent beings. It discusses the requirements for life, including non-equilibrium thermodynamics, a solvent (primarily water), and essential elements like carbon. Alternative solvents like ammonia and hydrocarbons are also considered. The section examines the possibility of different biochemistries, including the potential for silicon-based life, while noting the advantages of carbon. It also touches on the role of natural selection, replication, and cell membranes in the evolution of life.

Harsh Environmental Conditions on Earth Harboring Life üîó

This section highlights the discovery of life thriving in extreme environments on Earth, such as hydrothermal vents and acidic hot springs. These environments, once considered uninhabitable, provide parallels to the harsh conditions found on other planets and support the possibility of extraterrestrial life existing in similar extreme conditions. The section emphasizes the importance of chemical reactions, such as chemosynthesis, in sustaining life in these environments, particularly in the absence of oxygen.

Planetary Habitability in the Solar System üîó

This section assesses the potential for life on various bodies within our solar system. Besides Earth, Mars, Europa, and Enceladus are identified as the most promising candidates. Venus is discussed as a terrestrial planet that may have once been similar to Earth. Mars is considered a potential site for past or present microbial life. The subsurface oceans of Europa, Ganymede, Callisto, and Enceladus are explored as possible habitats. Titan, with its hydrocarbon lakes and subsurface ocean, is also mentioned as a unique environment that could potentially support life with different biochemistry.

Scientific Search üîó

This section outlines the scientific methods used to search for extraterrestrial life. Astrobiology, the science dedicated to this search, combines astronomy, biology, chemistry, geology, and other disciplines. The search encompasses both direct and indirect methods, including the analysis of telescope data, specimen data, and the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI).

Search for Basic Life üîó

This section focuses on the search for biosignatures, indicators of life, within the solar system and beyond. It mentions past claims of evidence for microbial life on Mars, including structures resembling nanobacteria in the ALH84001 meteorite and gas emissions detected by the Viking landers. The Mars Science Laboratory and the Curiosity rover are highlighted as ongoing efforts to assess the habitability of Mars. The section also mentions the creation of a catalog of microorganisms and their reactions to sunlight to aid in the search for similar organisms on exoplanets. The discovery of organic molecules, including nucleobases and sugars, in meteorites and cosmic dust is presented as evidence that the building blocks of life may be widespread in the universe. The detection of hydrogen cyanide in the plumes of Enceladus is also mentioned as a possible chemical essential for life.

Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligences üîó

This section discusses the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI) through the detection of technosignatures, indicators of technology. It mentions the SETI Institute’s search for radio waves and laser pulses. It also explores the possibility of detecting atmospheric effects, such as air pollution, and planetary-sized structures, such as Dyson spheres. The Green Bank Telescope is mentioned as one of the radio telescopes used by the Breakthrough Listen project.

Extrasolar Planets üîó

This section focuses on the search for exoplanets, particularly terrestrial planets within the habitable zones of their stars. It notes the discovery of thousands of exoplanets and the role of the Kepler space telescope in this effort. The section mentions the estimate that at least one in five Sun-like stars has an Earth-sized planet in the habitable zone. Proxima Centauri b is identified as the nearest known exoplanet. The section also discusses the analysis of exoplanet atmospheres for signs of oxygen and other biosignatures.

History and Cultural Impact üîó

This section explores the historical and cultural context of the search for extraterrestrial life.

Cosmic Pluralism üîó

This section traces the philosophical belief in numerous worlds beyond Earth, known as cosmic pluralism, back to ancient Greece. It contrasts the atomist view of Epicurus, who believed that other worlds with their own animals and plants should exist, with the Aristotelian view that Earth was the only planet in the universe. The section also mentions the support for cosmic pluralism in ancient Jainism and by medieval Muslim writers.

Early Modern Period üîó

This section discusses the impact of the Copernican Revolution and the heliocentric model on the concept of extraterrestrial life. It mentions Nicolaus Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Johannes Kepler, and Galileo Galilei as key figures in this shift. Giordano Bruno is highlighted as an early proponent of the idea of an infinite universe with countless planetary systems. The section also notes the resistance to these new ideas from the Catholic Church.

19th Century üîó

This section focuses on the increased speculation about life on Mars in the late 19th century, fueled by telescopic observations of apparent Martian canals. Percival Lowell is mentioned as a prominent proponent of the idea that these canals were the work of a civilization. The section also notes the spectroscopic analysis of Mars’s atmosphere, which revealed the absence of water and oxygen. The disproving of spontaneous generation by Louis Pasteur is mentioned, as well as the rise of the science fiction genre and its influence on public perception of extraterrestrial life.

Recent History üîó

This section discusses the development of astrobiology as a scientific discipline. It mentions NASA, ESA, and INAF as organizations involved in astrobiology research. The section also notes the emergence of pseudosciences, such as ufology and the ancient astronauts hypothesis, in response to public interest in extraterrestrial life. It also mentions the Rare Earth hypothesis, which argues that complex life is uncommon in the universe. The section concludes by noting the ongoing scientific efforts to search for extraterrestrial life and the technological advances that may make it possible to detect it.

Government Responses üîó

This section outlines the government policies and actions related to extraterrestrial life. It mentions the Outer Space Treaty and the Moon Agreement as defining rules of planetary protection. COSPAR is also mentioned as providing guidelines for planetary protection. The section notes that the UN lacks response mechanisms for the case of an extraterrestrial contact. NASA’s Office of Safety and Mission Assurance (OSMA) is highlighted for its mission to prevent backward contamination of Earth by extraterrestrial life. The space programs of China, Russia, France, and Israel are also mentioned as having objectives related to the search for extraterrestrial life.

In Fiction üîó

This section explores the portrayal of extraterrestrial life in fiction. It notes that early depictions of aliens were often similar to humans, but that the theory of evolution led to the creation of more diverse and bizarre aliens. The section mentions the influence of real-life events, such as the Barney and Betty Hill incident, on the depiction of aliens in fiction, particularly the grey alien archetype.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life

item.title: Area 51
item.description:
Area 51 üîó

Area 51, officially called Homey Airport (KXTA) or Groom Lake, is a highly classified United States Air Force (USAF) facility located within the Nevada Test and Training Range. It’s a remote detachment administered by Edwards Air Force Base. While details of its operations are not public, it’s believed to support the development and testing of experimental aircraft and weapons systems. The USAF and CIA acquired the site in 1955, primarily for flight testing the Lockheed U-2 aircraft. The intense secrecy surrounding the base has made it the subject of conspiracy theories and UFO folklore. The CIA publicly acknowledged the base’s existence in 2013, following a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request. It’s located in southern Nevada, 83 miles (134 km) north-northwest of Las Vegas.

Geography üîó

Area 51 üîó

The original rectangular base is part of the “Groom box,” a rectangular area of restricted airspace. It’s connected to the Nevada Test Site (NTS) road network, with roads leading to Mercury and Yucca Flat. Groom Lake Road runs northeast through the Jumbled Hills, past a security checkpoint, and descends to the Tikaboo Valley, converging with State Route 375, the “Extraterrestrial Highway,” south of Rachel. Area 51 shares a border with the Yucca Flat region of the Nevada Test Site, the location of numerous nuclear tests. The Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository is southwest of Groom Lake.

Groom Lake üîó

Groom Lake is a salt flat in Nevada used for runways of the Nellis Bombing Range Test Site airport (XTA/KXTA) on the north of the Area 51 USAF military installation. The lake is approximately 3+3‚ÅÑ4 mi (6 km) from north to south and 3 mi (5 km) from east to west at its widest point. It is located within the Groom Lake Valley portion of the Tonopah Basin, 25 mi (40 km) south of Rachel, Nevada.

History üîó

The origin of the name “Area 51” is unclear. The correct names for the facility are Homey Airport (XTA/KXTA) and Groom Lake. The facility has also been referred to as “Dreamland” and “Paradise Ranch.” The special use airspace around the field is referred to as Restricted Area 4808 North (R-4808N). Lead and silver were discovered in the Groom Range in 1864, and mining continued until the early 1950s. The airfield began service in 1942 as Indian Springs Air Force Auxiliary Field.

U-2 program üîó

The CIA established the Groom Lake test facility in April 1955 for Project AQUATONE: the development of the Lockheed U-2 strategic reconnaissance aircraft. Project director Richard M. Bissell Jr. chose Groom Lake as the testing site. Kelly Johnson, Lockheed’s U-2 designer, found the lake bed ideal for testing aircraft. The CIA asked the AEC to acquire the land, designated “Area 51,” and add it to the Nevada Test Site. Johnson named the area “Paradise Ranch.” The Ranch initially consisted of shelters, workshops, and trailer homes. By July 1955, the base consisted of a paved runway, three hangars, a control tower, and accommodations for test personnel. The Ranch received its first U-2 delivery on 24 July 1955.

OXCART program üîó

Project OXCART was established in August 1959 for work on the Lockheed A-12. This included testing at Groom Lake, which had inadequate facilities. A-12 test facility construction began in September 1960, including a new runway. Reynolds Electrical and Engineering Company (REECo) began construction of “Project 51” on 1 October 1960. The contractor upgraded base facilities and built a new 10,000 ft (3,000 m) runway. They marked an Archimedean spiral on the dry lake. By August 1961, construction of the essential facilities was complete. A permanent aircraft fuel tank farm was constructed by early 1962 for the special JP-7 fuel required by the A-12. Security was enhanced, and the FAA expanded the restricted airspace. The CIA facility received various USAF aircraft for training and support. The first A-12 test aircraft arrived at Groom Lake on 28 February 1962 and made its first flight 26 April 1962. Groom was also the site of the first Lockheed D-21 drone test flight on 22 December 1964. By the end of 1963, nine A-12s were at Area 51, assigned to the CIA-operated “1129th Special Activities Squadron”.

D-21 Tagboard üîó

Following the loss of Gary Powers’ U-2 over the Soviet Union, there were discussions about using the A-12 OXCART as an unpiloted drone aircraft. The Air Force agreed to fund the study of a high-speed, high-altitude drone aircraft in October 1962. The project designated “Q-12” was renamed the “D-21”. “Tagboard” was the project’s code name. The first D-21 was completed in the spring of 1964 by Lockheed. It was to be carried by a two-seat derivative of the A-12, designated the “M-21”. Difficulties were addressed throughout 1964 and 1965 at Groom Lake with various technical issues. The first D-21 launch was made on 5 March 1966 with a successful flight. An accident on 30 July 1966 with a fully fueled D-21 caused it to collide with the M-21 launch aircraft, resulting in one crew member drowning. Kelly Johnson cancelled the entire program. A number of D-21s had already been produced, and Johnson proposed to the Air Force that they be launched from a B-52H bomber. Several more tests, including two over China, were made from Beale AFB, California, in 1969 and 1970, to varying degrees of success. On 15 July 1971, Kelly Johnson received a wire canceling the D-21B program.

Foreign technology evaluation üîó

During the Cold War, one of the missions carried out by the United States was the test and evaluation of captured Soviet fighter aircraft. Beginning in the late 1960s, and for several decades, Area 51 played host to an assortment of Soviet-built aircraft. Munir Redfa’s defection with a Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 from Iraq for Israel’s Mossad in Operation Diamond led to the HAVE DOUGHNUT, HAVE DRILL and HAVE FERRY programs. The first MiGs flown in the United States were used to evaluate the aircraft in performance, technical, and operational capabilities, pitting the types against U.S. fighters. In August 1966, Iraqi Air Force fighter pilot Captain Munir Redfa defected, flying his MiG-21 to Israel. His aircraft was transferred to Groom Lake in late 1967 for study. In 1968, the US Air Force and Navy jointly formed a project known as HAVE DOUGHNUT in which Air Force Systems Command, Tactical Air Command, and the U.S. Navy’s Air Test and Evaluation Squadron Four (VX-4) flew this acquired Soviet-made aircraft in simulated air combat training. On 12 August 1968, two Syrian air force lieutenants landed at the Betzet Landing Field in northern Israel with a pair of MiG-17s. Prior to the end of 1968 these MiG-17s were transferred from Israeli stocks and added to the Area 51 test fleet. The data from the HAVE DOUGHNUT and HAVE DRILL tests were provided to the newly formed Top Gun school at NAS Miramar. In May 1973, Project HAVE IDEA was formed, which took over from the older HAVE DOUGHNUT, HAVE FERRY and HAVE DRILL projects, and the project was transferred to the Tonopah Test Range Airport. Area 51 also hosted another foreign materiel evaluation program called HAVE GLIB. The Air Force began funding improvements to Area 51 in 1977 under project SCORE EVENT. In 1979, the CIA transferred jurisdiction of the Area 51 site to the Air Force Flight Test Center at Edwards AFB, California. In 2017, a USAF aircraft crashed at the site, killing the pilot, Lt. Colonel Eric “Doc” Schultz.

Have Blue/F-117 program üîó

The Lockheed Have Blue prototype stealth fighter first flew at Groom in December 1977. In 1978, the Air Force awarded a full-scale development contract for the F-117 to Lockheed Corporation’s Advanced Development Projects. On 17 January 1981 the Lockheed test team at Area 51 accepted delivery of the first full-scale development (FSD) prototype 79‚Äì780, designated YF-117A. On 18 June 198

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Area_51

item.title: Crop circle
item.description:
Crop Circle üîó

A crop circle, also known as a crop formation or corn circle, is a pattern created by flattening a crop, usually a cereal. The term was coined in the early 1980s. While fringe theorists suggest obscure natural or alien origins, there is no scientific evidence for such explanations, and all crop circles are consistent with human causation. In 1991, Doug Bower and Dave Chorley, two hoaxers, claimed responsibility for creating over 200 crop circles throughout England. Reported circles often appear near roads, populated areas, and cultural heritage monuments like Stonehenge and Avebury, typically appearing overnight. Archaeological remains can cause cropmarks, but these are different from crop circles as they don’t appear overnight and are always in the same locations.

History üîó

Before the 20th Century üîó

A 1678 news pamphlet, The Mowing-Devil: or, Strange News Out of Hartfordshire, describes a crop with cut stalks. In 1686, naturalist Robert Plot reported on rings of mushrooms, proposing air flows from the sky as a cause. In 1991, meteorologist Terence Meaden linked this report with modern crop circles. An 1880 letter to Nature by John Rand Capron describes circles of flattened crops possibly caused by “cyclonic wind action.”

20th Century üîó

In 1932, archaeologist E. C. Curwen observed dark rings in a field at Stoughton Down near Chichester. David Wood reported making crop circles near Gloucestershire in 1940 using ropes. In 1963, Patrick Moore described a crater in a potato field in Wiltshire and circular areas in nearby wheat fields, suggesting air currents from the impact as a cause. Astronomer Hugh Ernest Butler suggested lightning strikes. During the 1960s, there were reports of UFO sightings and circular formations in swamp reeds and sugarcane fields in Tully, Queensland, Australia, and in Canada. In 1966, a farmer in Tully witnessed a saucer-shaped craft rise from a swamp, leaving a circular area of flattened grass. British pranksters Doug Bower and Dave Chorley reported starting to create crop circles in British cornfields in 1978, inspired by the Tully “saucer nest” case. The 1974 film Phase IV depicted a geometric crop circle created by super-intelligent ants. Reports of crop circles increased in the late 1970s, becoming widely known in the late 1980s after media coverage in Hampshire and Wiltshire. By 2001, approximately 10,000 crop circles had been reported internationally.

21st Century üîó

Crop formations have increased in size and complexity, with some featuring as many as 2,000 different shapes and incorporating complex mathematical and scientific characteristics. Jeremy Northcote found that crop circles in the UK in 2002 were not randomly spread but appeared near roads, populated areas, and cultural heritage monuments, suggesting intentional human action.

Bower and Chorley üîó

In 1991, Doug Bower and Dave Chorley claimed to have started the crop circle phenomenon in 1978, using simple tools. They demonstrated their method to journalists, fooling “cereologist” Pat Delgado. They claimed responsibility for all circles made prior to 1987 and for over 200 crop circles in 1978‚Äì1991. Richard Taylor noted that their creations inspired a second wave of crop artists.

Art and Business üîó

Increasingly complex geometric designs have been created by anonymous artists, sometimes to attract tourists. The UK arts collective Circlemakers, founded by Rod Dickinson and John Lundberg, has been creating crop circles as art and for commercial clients. The Led Zeppelin Boxed Set featured an image of a crop circle. A crop-circle-making competition was held in Berkshire in 1992, with the winning entry produced by Westland Helicopters engineers. In 2002, Discovery Channel commissioned MIT graduate students to create crop circles. In 2009, The Guardian reported that crop circle activity had been waning around Wiltshire, as makers preferred creating promotional crop circles for companies. A video sequence used in the 2012 Summer Olympics opening in London showed crop circles in the shape of the Olympic rings. A crop circle depicting the Star Wars Rebel Alliance emblem was created in California in 2017.

Legal Implications üîó

In 1992, G√°bor Tak√°cs and R√≥bert Dallos were the first people to face legal action after creating a crop circle in Hungary. They were sued for damages, but the judge ruled they were only responsible for the damage caused in the circle itself. In 2000, Matthew Williams became the first man in the UK to be arrested for causing criminal damage after making a crop circle near Devizes.

Creation üîó

Human Origin üîó

The scientific consensus is that crop circles are constructed by human beings as hoaxes, advertising, or art. A common method involves using a rope and board to flatten the plants. Skeptics point out that all characteristics of crop circles are compatible with human creation. Bower and Chorley confessed to making the first crop circles in southern England. Increasingly complex circles started appearing worldwide, with physicists suggesting that the most complex formations might be made with GPS and lasers.

Natural Origins üîó

Weather üîó

It has been suggested that crop circles may be the result of extraordinary meteorological phenomena, but there is no evidence of any crop circle being created by these causes. In 1880, John Rand Capron blamed circles in crops on a recent storm. In 1980, Terence Meaden proposed that the circles were caused by whirlwinds. Stephen Hawking said that “Corn circles are either hoaxes or formed by vortex movement of air.”

Animal Activity üîó

In 2009, the attorney general for Tasmania stated that wallabies had been found creating crop circles in fields of opium poppies after consuming them.

Alternative Explanations üîó

Paranormal üîó

Since the 1980s, crop circles have been the subject of speculation by paranormal, ufological, and anomalistic investigators, ranging from bizarre meteorological phenomena to messages from extraterrestrial beings. Some speculate that crop circles have a relation to ley lines. Some paranormal advocates think that crop circles are caused by ball lightning and controlled by some entity, such as Gaia, God, supernatural beings, the collective minds of humanity, or extraterrestrial beings. The Indonesian National Institute of Aeronautics and Space (LAPAN) described crop circles as “man-made.” No credible evidence of extraterrestrial origin has been presented.

Changes to Crops üîó

Some scientists have claimed to observe differences between the crops inside the circles and outside them, citing this as evidence they were not man-made. Joe Nickell objected to these claims, raising objections to the methods and assumptions.

Related Art üîó

Patterns similar to crop circles can also be made in snow, sand, and forests.

Folklore üîó

Researchers have linked modern crop circles to old folkloric tales. Crop circles appear mostly in developed and secularized Western countries where people are receptive to New Age beliefs. Fungi can cause circular areas of crop to die, the origin of tales of “fairie rings.” A 17th-century English woodcut, the Mowing-Devil, depicts the devil mowing a circular design in a field of oats. In the 1948 German story Die zw√∂lf Schw√§ne, a farmer finds a circular ring of flattened grain in his field every morning, caused by princesses disguised as swans dancing in the field.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crop_circle

item.title: Ancient astronauts
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts üîó

Ancient astronauts, also known as ancient aliens, is a pseudoscientific belief that intelligent extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in ancient times and influenced the development of human civilization. Proponents suggest that these aliens affected modern cultures, technologies, religions, and human biology. A common idea is that deities from religions are extraterrestrial in origin, and advanced technologies were seen as divine by early humans. Academics and archaeologists dismiss these claims as pseudoarchaeological or unscientific, lacking credible peer-reviewed studies. Some argue that these theories have racist undertones, diminishing the accomplishments of indigenous cultures.

Overview üîó

Various terms are used to describe claims about ancient astronauts, including ancient aliens, ancient ufonauts, ancient space pilots, paleocontact, astronaut- or alien gods, and paleo- or biblical-SETI. Believers often claim that humans are descendants or creations of extraterrestrial intelligence who landed on Earth in the past. They also suggest that human knowledge, religion, and culture originated from these ancient extraterrestrial visitors, who acted as a “mother culture.” Proponents argue that aliens built or aided in building structures like the Egyptian pyramids and the Moai stone heads of Easter Island. Evidence is said to come from documentary gaps in historical and archaeological records, as well as artifacts believed to be anachronistic and beyond the technical capabilities of ancient people.

The idea is considered pseudoarcheology and is featured in fringe media like the History Channel series Ancient Aliens. Such shows mix fact with fiction to promote theories of an alternate past, often aligning with white supremacist, nativist, imperialist, settler-colonial, and Christian Identity beliefs. Proponents portray themselves as an oppressed minority of academics, claiming a conspiracy by ‘big archaeology’ to disenfranchise them. They focus on monumental archaeological structures, implying that non-white indigenous people could not have built them without extraterrestrial intervention. However, some indigenous voices argue that the idea of extraterrestrials supports their own origin stories. A common feature is the portrayal of aliens as light-skinned or Aryan, as claimed by Erich von D√§niken.

History of Ancient Aliens Beliefs and Their Proponents üîó

Paleocontact narratives first appeared in early science fiction of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Harold T. Wilkins proposed the idea in earnest in 1954. It gained popularity in the 1960s due to the Space Race and the success of Erich von D√§niken’s works. Critics emerged in the 1970s, discrediting Von D√§niken’s claims. By the early 1980s, support for the idea dwindled.

Shklovskii and Sagan üîó

Carl Sagan and Soviet astrophysicist Iosif Shklovsky co-authored Intelligent Life in the Universe in 1966. Sagan later expressed disapproval of writers like von D√§niken who built on their ideas without caution, presenting them as valid evidence of extraterrestrial contact. Sagan pointed out that many legends, artifacts, and purported out-of-place artifacts cited in support of ancient astronaut hypotheses could be easily explained with more conventional hypotheses.

Erich von D√§niken üîó

Erich von D√§niken became a leading proponent of the ancient astronaut hypothesis in the late 1960s and early 1970s, gaining a large audience through his book Chariots of the Gods? According to von D√§niken, certain artifacts required more sophisticated technology than was available to the ancient cultures that constructed them. He maintained that these artifacts were constructed either directly by extraterrestrial visitors or by humans who learned the necessary knowledge from them. These include Stonehenge, Pumapunku, the Moai of Easter Island, the Great Pyramid of Giza, and the ancient Baghdad electric batteries.

Von D√§niken wrote that ancient art and iconography throughout the world illustrate air and space vehicles, non-human but intelligent creatures, ancient astronauts, and artifacts of anachronistically advanced technology. He also stated that geographically separated historical cultures share artistic themes, implying a common origin. One example is his interpretation of the sarcophagus lid from the tomb of Pacal the Great in Palenque, which he saw as representing a seated astronaut. He interpreted the origins of many religions as reactions to encounters with an alien race, viewing the aliens’ technology as supernatural and the aliens themselves as gods.

Critics argue that von D√§niken misrepresented data, that many of his claims were unfounded, and that none of his core claims have been validated.

Zecharia Sitchin üîó

Zecharia Sitchin’s series The Earth Chronicles, beginning with The 12th Planet, revolves around Sitchin’s interpretation of ancient Sumerian and Middle Eastern texts, megalithic sites, and artifacts. He hypothesized that the gods of old Mesopotamia were astronauts from the planet “Nibiru,” which the Sumerians believed to be a remote “12th planet” associated with the god Marduk. According to Sitchin, Nibiru continues to orbit the Sun on a 3,600-year elongated orbit.

Sitchin argued that Sumerian texts tell the story that 50 Anunnaki from Nibiru came to Earth approximately 400,000 years ago to mine raw materials, especially gold. They eventually created Homo sapiens sapiens: the “Adapa” (model man) or Adam of later mythology. Sitchin contended the Anunnaki were active in human affairs until their culture was destroyed by global catastrophes caused by the abrupt end of the last ice age some 12,000 years ago.

Sitchin’s work has not received mainstream scholarly support and has been criticized by professionals. Semitic languages scholar Michael S. Heiser says that many of Sitchin’s translations of Sumerian and Mesopotamian words are not consistent with Mesopotamian cuneiform bilingual dictionaries.

Robert Temple üîó

Robert K. G. Temple’s 1976 book, The Sirius Mystery, argues that the Dogon people of northwestern Mali preserved an account of extraterrestrial visitation from around 5,000 years ago. He quotes various lines of evidence, including advanced astronomical knowledge inherited by the tribe, descriptions, and comparative belief systems with ancient civilizations such as ancient Egypt and Sumer. His work draws heavily on the studies of cultural anthropologists Marcel Griaule and Germaine Dieterlen.
