His conclusions have been criticized by scientists, who point out discrepancies within Temple’s account, and suggested that the Dogon may have received some of their astronomical information recently, probably from European sources, and may have misrepresented Dogon ethnography.

UFO Religions üîó

Various new religious movements including some branches of Theosophy, Scientology, Ra√´lism, Aetherius Society, and Heaven’s Gate believe in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence. Many of these faiths see both ancient scriptures and recent revelations as connected with the action of aliens from other planetary systems. Psychologists have found that UFO religions have similarities which suggest that members of these groups consciously or subliminally associate enchantment with the memes of science fiction.

Claims of Proponents üîó

Scientists generally agree that the ancient astronaut hypothesis is not impossible, but unjustified and unnecessary. The “mysteries” cited as evidence can be explained without invoking ancient astronauts. Since ancient astronauts are unnecessary, Occam’s razor should be applied and the hypothesis rejected.

Ancient Religious Texts üîó

Proponents cite ancient mythologies to support their viewpoints, suggesting that ancient creation myths of gods descending from the heavens to Earth to create or instruct humanity are representations of alien visitors. They draw an analogy to occurrences in modern time when isolated cultures are exposed to advanced technology, such as when “cargo cults” were discovered in the South Pacific.

The ancient Sumerian myth of En√ªma Eli≈°, inscribed on cuneiform tablets and part of the Library of Ashurbanipal, says humankind was created to serve gods called the “Annunaki”. Hypothesis proponents believe that the Annunaki were aliens who came to Earth to mine gold for their own uses and then created the human race as slaves.

Ramayana üîó

In Hindu mythology, the gods and their avatars travel in flying vehicles called Vimana. There are many mentions of these flying objects in the Ramayana. Erich von D√§niken discusses the Ramayana and the vimanas in Chariots of the Gods? suggesting that they were “space vehicles”.

The Bible üîó

Book of Genesis and Book of Enoch üîó

The Book of Genesis, Chapter 6 verses 1‚Äì2 and 4, states that the “sons of God” saw that the daughters of humans were beautiful, and they married any of them they chose. The Nephilim were on the earth in those days when the sons of God went to the daughters of humans and had children by them. Ancient Astronaut proponents argue that Adam and Eve ate of the forbidden fruit in order “to be godlike”, and this was the first step in human evolution.

The first part of the apocryphal Book of Enoch expands and interprets Genesis 6:1: that the “sons of God” were a group of 200 “angels” called “Watchers”, who descended to Earth to breed with humans. Their offspring are the Nephilim, “giants” who “consumed all the acquisitions of men”. The Watchers also instructed humans in metallurgy and metalworking, cosmetics, sorcery, astrology, astronomy, and meteorology. God then ordered the Watchers to be imprisoned in the ground, and created the Great Flood to rid Earth of the Nephilim and of the humans given knowledge by the Watch

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_astronauts

item.title: Alien Abduction
item.description:
Alien abduction (also called abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction) refers to the phenomenon of people reporting what they believe to be the real experience of being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation.[1] People claiming to have been abducted are usually called “abductees”[2] or “experiencers”. Most scientists and mental health professionals explain these experiences by factors such as suggestibility (e.g. false memory syndrome), sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology.[3] Skeptic Robert Sheaffer sees similarity between some of the aliens described by abductees and those depicted in science fiction films, in particular Invaders From Mars (1953).[4]

Typical claims involve forced medical examinations that emphasize the subject’s reproductive systems.[5] Abductees sometimes claim to have been warned against environmental abuses and the dangers of nuclear weapons,[6] or to have engaged in interspecies breeding.[7] The contents of the abduction narrative often seem to vary with the home culture of the alleged abductee.[4] Unidentified flying objects (UFOs), alien abduction, and mind control plots can also be part of radical political apocalyptic and millenarian narratives.[8]

reference: Alien Abduction

item.title: Extraterrestrials in fiction
item.description:
Fictional Depictions of Extraterrestrial Life üîó

This article provides an overview of how extraterrestrial life is portrayed in fiction, distinguishing it from claims of actual alien encounters. It emphasizes the prevalence of extraterrestrials as a theme in science fiction and other works.

History üîó

This section traces the evolution of extraterrestrial depictions in fiction, starting from ancient times to the modern era.

Antiquity üîó

This subsection discusses early examples of extraterrestrial life in literature, highlighting Lucian’s True History as a key example. It explains how early concepts of aliens were tied to the development of astronomy and the understanding of celestial objects as physical entities. Early depictions often portrayed extraterrestrials as human-like. Voltaire’s Microm√©gas and works by Johannes Kepler, Francis Godwin, and Cyrano de Bergerac are mentioned as examples where aliens differed from humans only in culture or habits.

The impact of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species is discussed, noting how it revolutionized the portrayal of aliens by inspiring authors to imagine non-humanoid extraterrestrial races. Camille Flammarion’s works are cited as some of the first to feature genuinely alien lifeforms. H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds and The First Men in the Moon are also mentioned as significant contributions.

The War of the Worlds is further analyzed for its use of Darwinian evolution, exploration of the implications of evolution, and critique of British imperialism. It also introduced the tropes of alien invasion and extraterrestrials as monsters. The First Men in the Moon is noted as an early attempt to describe an alien civilization in detail, drawing parallels to an ant colony.

The emergence of science fiction as a genre is mentioned, with Jules Verne’s works as examples of stories exploring extraterrestrials and space exploration.

Early 20th Century üîó

This section focuses on the role of pulp magazines in popularizing science fiction. It describes the common tropes of the era, including quasi-human aliens, monstrous invaders, and human conquest of alien worlds. The prevalence of aliens from planets and moons within the Solar System is noted. Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey is highlighted for its unique Martian ecosystem.

Modern Times üîó

This section discusses the evolution of alien depictions in more recent times. The Eternaut by H√©ctor Germ√°n Oesterheld is mentioned as a pioneering work of alien invasion set in Buenos Aires, serving as a critique of imperialism and military dictatorship.

The Barney and Betty Hill incident is discussed as a pivotal event that shaped the modern image of grey aliens. Steven Spielberg’s films, such as Close Encounters of the Third Kind and E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, are mentioned as influential works that popularized the grey alien archetype.

The impact of television and film on alien portrayals is noted, with Star Trek being mentioned as a franchise that popularized human-like aliens. Star Wars and Alien are also mentioned as significant franchises that contributed to the public’s interest in outer space.

The advent of computer-generated imagery (CGI) is discussed as a factor that allowed for the creation of more bizarre and diverse alien lifeforms.

Types üîó

This section categorizes the different ways extraterrestrials are portrayed in fiction. It covers variations in intelligence, biological aspects, and attitudes towards humanity. It also mentions the concept of extraterrestrials originating from unexplored areas of Earth, such as the sea, sky, underground, or other dimensions.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrials_in_fiction

item.title: List of alleged extraterrestrial beings
item.description:
List of Alleged Extraterrestrial Beings üîó

This Wikipedia entry catalogues various extraterrestrial beings that have been reported in alleged close encounters, claimed sightings, or speculated to be associated with unidentified flying objects (UFOs). It clarifies that the term “extraterrestrial being” in this context differs from the biological definition of “alien species” in ecology.

List üîó

This section presents a table listing alleged extraterrestrial beings, providing their names and brief descriptions.

  • Flatwoods Monster: A tall humanoid with a spade-shaped head, associated with the Flatwoods Monster incident.
  • Greys: Grey-skinned humanoids, typically around 1 meter tall, hairless, with large heads and black almond-shaped eyes. They are linked to the Roswell incident and have been a prominent feature in alleged alien contact since the 1960s.
  • Hopkinsville Goblin: Small, greenish-silver humanoids, connected to the Kelly‚ÄìHopkinsville encounter.
  • Little Green Men: Diminutive green humanoids, a classic cultural stereotype, though actual abduction reports rarely match this description.
  • Nordic Aliens: Humanoids with stereotypical “Nordic” features (tall, blonde hair, blue eyes), sometimes referred to as Space Brothers. This category includes Plejarens (previously known as Pleiadeans), Venusians, Tall Whites, and Agarthans from Agartha.
  • Cryptozoological Animals and Cryptobotanical Plants: Creatures from folklore, religion, and mythology (e.g., golems, dwarves, giants from Atlantis), as well as reports of ghosts, poltergeists, and time travelers. Examples include the Mothman, Jersey Devil, Loch Ness Monster, Nommo, Mokele-mbembe, Yokai, Quinametzin, Rephaite, and Loveland Frogman. It suggests that some believe these creatures are of extraterrestrial or mixed origin, as proposed in the extraterrestrial, interdimensional, or cryptoterrestrial hypotheses.
  • Reptilians and Reptiloids: Tall, scaly humanoids, sometimes linked to ancient astronauts. This category includes Draconians and Orion reptilian-humanoids. David Icke is mentioned as a proponent of the reptilian conspiracy theory.
  • Rods or Skyfish: Elongated visual artifacts appearing in photos and videos, sometimes claimed to be extraterrestrial beings, but generally believed to be caused by motion blur from flying insects.

See also üîó

This section provides a list of related Wikipedia articles, categorized as follows:

  • General Topics: Alien abduction, Alien abduction entities, Alleged extraterrestrial beings, Ancient astronauts, Chimera, Conspiracy theory, Contactees, Cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, Evolutionary biology, Extraterrestrial hypothesis, Genetic mutation, Horizontal evolution, Interdimensional hypothesis, List of conspiracy theories, List of cryptids, List of humanoid aliens, List of occult terms, MUFON (United States), Kosmopoisk (Russia), New World Order.
  • In Fiction: Template:Fictional biology, Category:Lists of fictional alien species, List of fictional extraterrestrials, Lists of fictional species, Template:Science fiction, Babylon 5, Battlestar Galactica, List of alien races in DC Comics, List of alien races in Marvel Comics, Mass Effect, Stargate, Star Trek, Star Wars, The Twilight Zone.

References üîó

This section lists the references cited in the article, providing sources for the information presented. Some key references include:

  • Clark, Jerome. Unexplained!
  • Nickell, Joe. “Investigative Files: The Flatwoods UFO Monster” and “Siege of ‘Little Green Men’: The 1955 Kelly, Kentucky, Incident.”
  • Bryan, C.D.B. Close Encounters of the Fourth Kind.
  • Blackmore, Susan. “Abduction by Aliens or Sleep Paralysis?”
  • Carlson, Peter. “Ike and the Alien Ambassadors.”
  • Lewis, Tyson; Kahn, Richard. “The Reptoid Hypothesis: Utopian and Dystopian Representational Motifs in David Icke’s Alien Conspiracy Theory.”

External links üîó

This section provides a link to Abducted: How People Come to Believe They Were Kidnapped by Aliens (2005) by Susan A. Clancy.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_alleged_extraterrestrial_beings

item.title: Unidentified flying object
item.description:
Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) üîó

An unidentified flying object (UFO), also known as unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) or unidentified anomalous phenomena, is defined as an object or phenomenon observed in the sky that cannot be immediately identified or explained. While reports of unusual aerial sightings date back to at least the 3rd century BC, the term “UFO” gained prominence after World War II and escalated during the Space Age. Most UFOs are later identified as known objects or atmospheric phenomena, but a small percentage remain unexplained. Government investigations and studies by organizations and individuals have occurred over the years, but there is no confirmation of claims that UFOs are evidence of extraterrestrial intelligence or other unconventional hypotheses. Scientists and skeptic organizations often attribute UFOs to natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, and hoaxes. The ongoing interest in UFOs is seen by social scientists as a modern example of folklore and mythology. The U.S. government has entities dedicated to UFO data collection and analysis: NASA’s UAP independent study team and the Department of Defence All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office.

Terminology üîó

During the late 1940s and 1950s, UFOs were often called “flying saucers” or “flying discs” based on the Kenneth Arnold incident. The term “unidentified flying object” (UFO) has been in use since 1947. Captain Edward J. Ruppelt coined the acronym “UFO” for the USAF. “Unidentified aerial phenomena” (UAP) first appeared in the late 1960s and has seen increasing usage in the 21st century. While technically a UFO refers to any unidentified flying object, in modern popular culture the term UFO has generally become synonymous with alien spacecraft. The term “extra-terrestrial vehicle” (ETV) is sometimes used to separate this explanation of UFOs from totally earthbound explanations.

Identification üîó

Studies show that after careful investigation, the majority of UFOs can be identified as ordinary objects or phenomena. The 1952‚Äì1955 study for the USAF used categories such as “Balloon; Astronomical; Aircraft; Light phenomenon; Birds, Clouds, dust, etc.; Insufficient information; Psychological manifestations; Unknown; and Other”. Identified sources of UFO reports include aircraft, astronomical objects, balloons, hoaxes, light phenomena, other atmospheric objects and phenomena, and psychological effects. A 1979 study by CUFOS researcher Allan Hendry found that fewer than one percent of cases he investigated were hoaxes and most sightings were actually honest misidentifications of prosaic phenomena. Astronomer Andrew Fraknoi advised his students to apply critical thinking to UFO claims, stating that the more you investigate, the more likely you are to find that there is LESS to these stories than meets the eye.

History üîó

Early history before the 20th century üîó

Throughout history, people have observed unusual sights in the sky, including comets, meteors, planets, and optical phenomena. Halley’s Comet, first recorded by Chinese astronomers in 240 BC, was often treated as a supernatural portent or omen. Some examples of pre-contemporary reports about unusual aerial phenomena include:

  • Julius Obsequens, a Roman writer, made references to things moving through the sky in his Liber de prodigiis.
  • Shen Kuo (1031‚Äì1095), a Song Chinese government official, wrote about an unidentified flying object in his Dream Pool Essays (1088).
  • A woodcut by Hans Glaser in 1561 depicts the “celestial phenomenon over Nuremberg,” which has been connected to ancient astronaut claims.
  • A similar report comes from 1566 over Basel.
  • On January 25, 1878, the Denison Daily News printed an article in which John Martin, a local farmer, had reported seeing a large, dark, circular object resembling a balloon flying “at wonderful speed”.

20th century and after üîó

In the Pacific and European theatres during World War II, round, glowing fireballs known as “foo fighters” were reported by Allied and Axis pilots. In 1946, more than 2,000 reports were collected, primarily by the Swedish military, of unidentified aerial objects over the Scandinavian nations, along with isolated reports from France, Portugal, Spain, Italy, and Greece. The objects were referred to as “Russian hail” (and later as “ghost rockets”).

The popular UFO craze in the US began with a media frenzy surrounding the reports on June 24, 1947, of a civilian pilot named Kenneth Arnold who described seeing “a group of bat-like aircraft flying in formation at high speeds” near Mount Rainier that he said were “moving like a saucer would if skipped across water” which led to headlines about “flying saucers” and “flying discs”. Within weeks, reports of flying saucer sightings became a daily occurrence with one particularly famous example being the Roswell incident in 1947. In 1950, three influential books were published‚ÄîDonald Keyhoe’s The Flying Saucers Are Real, Frank Scully’s Behind the Flying Saucers, and Gerald Heard’s The Riddle of the Flying Saucers.

Media accounts and speculation ran rampant in the U.S., especially in connection to the 1952 UFO scare in Washington, D.C. so that, by 1953, the intelligence officials worried that “genuine incursions” by enemy aircraft “over U.S. territory could be lost in a maelstrom of kooky hallucination” of UFO reports. The cultural phenomenon showed up within some intellectual works such as the 1959 publication of Flying Saucers: A Modern Myth of Things Seen in the Sky by Carl Jung.

Starting in 1947, the U.S. Air Force began to record and investigated UFO reports with Project Sign looking into “more than 250 cases” from 1947 to 1949. It was replaced by Project Grudge up through 1951. In the third U.S. Air Force program, from March 1952 to its termination in December 1969, “the U.S. Air Force cataloged 12,618 sightings of UFOs as part of what is now known as Project Blue Book”. Official U.S. Air Force interest in UFO reports went on hiatus in 1969 after a study by the University of Colorado led by Edward U. Condon and known as the Condon Report concluded “that nothing has come from the study of UFOs in the past 21 years that has added to scientific knowledge” and that further time investigating UFO reports “cannot be justified”.

From the 1960s to 1990s, UFOs were part of American popular culture’s obsession with the supernatural and paranormal. In 1961, the first alien abduction account was sensationalized when Barney and Betty Hill underwent hypnosis after seeing a UFO and reported recovered memories of their experience that became ever more elaborate as the years went by.

In December 2017, a new round of media attention started when The New York Times broke the story of the secret Advanced Aviation Threat Identification Program that was funded from 2007 to 2012 with $22 million spent on the program. Following this story, along with a series of sensationalized Pentagon UFO videos leaked by members of the program who became convinced that UFOs were genuine mysteries worth investigating, there was an increase in mainstream attention to UFO stories. In July 2021, Harvard astronomer Avi Loeb announced the creation of his Galileo Project which intended to use high-tech astronomical equipment to seek evidence of extraterrestrial artifacts in space and possibly within Earth’s atmosphere. Two government sponsored programs, NASA’s UAP independent study team and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office were charged in part by Congressional fiat to investigate UFO claims more fully, adopting the new moniker “unexplained aerial phenomenon” (UAP) to avoid associations with past sensationalism. On 17 May 2022, members of the United States House Intelligence Subcommittee on Counterterrorism, Counterintelligence and Counterproliferation held congressional hearings with top military officials to discuss military reports of UAPs. Another Congressional hearing took place on July 26, 2023, featuring the whistleblower claims of former U.S. Air Force (USAF) officer and intelligence official David Grusch.

A Harris Poll in 2009 found that 32% of Americans “believe in UFOs”. A National Geographic study in June 2012 found that 36% of Americans believe UFOs exist and that 10% thought that they had spotted one. In June 2021 a Pew research poll found that 51% in the United States thought that UFOs reported by people in the military were likely to be evidence of intelligent life from beyond the Earth.

Notable cases and incidents üîó

Britain üîó

  • The Rendlesham Forest incident was a series of reported sightings of unexplained lights near Rendlesham Forest in Suffolk, England in late December 1980 which became linked with claims of UFO landings.

France üîó

The most notable cases of UFO sightings in France include:

  • the Valensole UFO incident in 1965.
  • the Trans

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unidentified_flying_object

item.title: Alien Hominid
item.description:
Alien Hominid üîó

Alien Hominid is a run and gun video game developed by The Behemoth. It initially launched as a Flash game on Newgrounds in 2002, created by Tom Fulp and Dan Paladin. Later, expanded versions were released on various consoles and computers.

Gameplay üîó

This section details the gameplay mechanics of Alien Hominid, comparing it to games like Metal Slug. The game is a side-scrolling run and gun shooter where one hit kills the player. Players control the titular alien, fending off waves of secret agents using a blaster, melee attacks, and grenades. Advanced moves include rolling, head-biting, and digging underground. Power-ups provide extra grenades, shields, and unique ammo. Players can also drive vehicles, ride a Yeti, and pilot a UFO. Completing tasks unlocks hats for the Hominid. The main game consists of sixteen stages. Additional multiplayer modes include Challenge, Neutron Ball, and Pinata Boss. There’s also a PDA game with around 200 levels and a level editor, an extra mode called All You Can Eat, and a retro minigame, Super Soviet Missile Mastar.

Plot üîó

This section outlines the game’s storyline. The Alien Hominid’s spacecraft is intercepted by the FBI, causing it to crash on Earth. The FBI steals the ship, leading the alien to pursue them with the help of “fat kids.” After retrieving the ship, the alien crashes into a Soviet missile, landing in Russia. The alien recovers the ship again, only to be captured by an Area 51 spaceship. The alien escapes, befriends a sentient eyeball, and defeats a buff alien. The “fat kids” help the alien and eyeball escape in the alien’s ship, using a tractor beam to lift the kids out of an Area 51 truck.

Reception üîó

This section summarizes the critical reception of Alien Hominid across different platforms. The game received generally favorable reviews, with high scores from publications like GameRankings, Metacritic, Edge, Electronic Gaming Monthly, Eurogamer, Game Informer, GamePro, Game Revolution, GameSpot, GameSpy, GameTrailers, GameZone, IGN, Nintendo Power, Official U.S. PlayStation Magazine, Official Xbox Magazine, Detroit Free Press, and The Times. The game was praised for its old-school gameplay, difficulty, and humor. It won awards at the Independent Games Festival.

Legacy üîó

This section discusses the game’s impact and references in other games. The Hominid appears in The Behemoth’s Castle Crashers and is playable in Super Meat Boy. The Super Soviet Missile Mastar minigame was released as a free iOS app. The PDA Games minigame inspired The Behemoth’s BattleBlock Theater. In 2020, The Behemoth announced Alien Hominid Invasion, a reimagining of the original game, released in 2023 alongside a remaster of the original, Alien Hominid HD.

Notes üîó

This section provides additional information about the game’s development and publishing. Tuna Technologies ported the game to Game Boy Advance and J2ME. Zoo Digital Publishing and O3 Entertainment published the PlayStation 2, GameCube, Xbox, and Game Boy Advance versions in Europe and North America. Allister Brimble and Anthony N. Putson composed the Game Boy Advance music.

References üîó

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including reviews, news articles, and official websites.

External links üîó

This section provides links to external resources related to the game, including the official U.S. website, the original Flash prototype, The Behemoth’s website, and Tuna Technologies’ website.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Hominid

item.title: Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe
item.description:
Alliance‚ÄìUnion Universe üîó

The Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe is a fictional setting created by C. J. Cherryh for her science fiction novels. It spans the third and fourth millennia and focuses on humanity’s expansion into space. The universe is dominated by three major powers: Earth Company, the Alliance, and the Union. The Earth Company’s control is challenged by the Alliance and the Union, leading to conflicts and wars. The universe also includes various alien species and explores themes of cultural identity, political maneuvering, and technological advancement.

Description üîó

This section provides an overview of the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe. It highlights the three main economic powers: Earth Company, the Alliance, and the Union. The Earth Company represents the original power based on Earth, while the Alliance is a confederation of trade merchants, and the Union is a breakaway government from the planet Cyteen. The section mentions the Company Wars, where the Earth Company’s attempts to control space expansion are thwarted. It also introduces the concept of azi, cloned humans used by the Union. The section references Patricia Monk’s idea of the series forming a “megatext” or “collage novel” due to the interconnectedness of Cherryh’s works within this universe.

History üîó

This section details the historical timeline of the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe. It begins with humanity’s initial expansion into space, financed by the Sol Corporation (later Earth Company). The development of space stations and the emergence of distinct cultural identities among stationers and merchanters are discussed. The discovery of Pell’s World and its native species, the Hisa, disrupts the existing power balance. The development of faster-than-light (FTL) travel leads to Earth’s attempts to reassert control, resulting in unrest and the formation of the Union. The Company War ensues, with the Union utilizing cloned soldiers (azi). The conflict culminates at Pell Station, leading to the formation of the Alliance as a neutral power. Conrad Mazian’s rebellion and Signy Mallory’s defection are mentioned, along with the eventual establishment of a peace treaty and the rise of tensions between the Alliance and the Union. The section also touches on the political factions within the Union and the role of Ariane Emory.

Genre üîó

This section classifies the various works within the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe by genre. Many of the stories are described as space opera or planetary romances. Works like Cyteen and Downbelow Station are considered hard science fiction. The “Company Wars” novels and the Faded Sun trilogy are examples of military science fiction. The Merovingen Nights series is classified as science fantasy, while Voyager in Night incorporates elements of horror fiction.

Books and Reading Order üîó

This section provides guidance on the order in which to read the books set in the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe. C. J. Cherryh states that most books can be read in any order, with two exceptions: Heavy Time and Hellburner should be read in that order, and Cyteen and Regenesis should be read in sequence. The novels in the Faded Sun trilogy, the Chanur novels, and the Morgaine series are also designed to be read in order. The Merovingen Nights series begins with Angel with the Sword and continues with the short story anthologies.

Major Characters üîó

This section lists and describes some of the key characters in the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe. These include:

  • Pyanfar Chanur: Hani captain and leader of the Compact.
  • Sten Duncan: Alliance soldier who joins the Mri.
  • Ariane Emory-1 and Ariane Emory-2 PR: Scientist and her clone from Union.
  • Damon Konstantin and Elene Quen: Leaders of the Merchanter Alliance.
  • Conrad Mazian: Commander of the Earth Company Fleet and later leader of the Mazianni.
  • Signy Mallory: Captain who defects to the Alliance.
  • Elizabeth McGee: Union scientist.
  • James Robert Neihart: Captain and negotiator for the Merchanter Alliance.
  • Kurt Morgan: Survivor of the Alliance ship Endymion.
  • Raen a Sul hant Meth-maren: Human mediator with the Majat.
  • Thorn: Human raised by the Shonunin.

Sentient Alien Species üîó

This section details the various sentient alien species that inhabit the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe. It includes a table listing the species name, home system, home planet, the works in which they appear, and notes about their characteristics. Some of the notable species include:

  • Hani: Feline humanoids from Ahr.
  • Hisa: Peaceful mammalians from Pell’s World.
  • Mri: Militaristic humanoids from Na’i’in.
  • Kif: Carnivorous humanoids from Akkt.
  • Majat: Hive-mind insectoids from Alpha Hydri.

Planets üîó

This section describes some of the key planets in the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe:

  • Pell’s World: A planet orbiting Tau Ceti, notable for its ecosystem, the Hisa, and its impact on the balance of power.
  • Gehenna: A planet in the Zeta Reticuli system, home to the calibans and secretly colonized by the Union.
  • Cyteen: A planet deep in Union territory, known for its toxic atmosphere, terraforming efforts, and the source of the rejuvenation drug.
  • Merovin: An isolated planet with backwards technology due to poor interstellar relations.

Technologies üîó

This section outlines the advanced technologies present in the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe. These include:

  • Jump Drive: Enables faster-than-light travel.
  • Rejuv: A life-extension drug.
  • Human Cloning: Used extensively by the Union to create azi.
  • Tape: Subliminal conditioning and information transfer.
  • Terraforming: Used to make planets like Cyteen habitable.

Society üîó

This section explores the societal structures and cultural differences within the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe. It highlights the divergence in attitudes between planet-dwellers, space station-dwellers, and starship crews. It also discusses the cultural and psychological division between citizens and azi in the Union.

Mazianni üîó

This section focuses on the Mazianni, the military starships and their crews who remain loyal to Conrad Mazian after he renounces his allegiance to Earth. It describes their origins as the Earth Company Fleet, their rebellion, and their subsequent guerrilla warfare tactics.

Songs üîó

This section mentions a collection of songs written by C. J. Cherryh about the station trade in the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe. These songs were recorded by filk musician Leslie Fish and released on an album titled Finity’s End.

Critical Reception üîó

This section summarizes the critical reception of the Alliance‚ÄìUnion universe. John Clute calls it Cherryh’s “central achievement,” while M. Keith Booker describes it as “so far-reaching that its overall outlines remain unclear and continue to develop.”

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hisa_(fictional_alien_species)

item.title: Ashtar (extraterrestrial being)
item.description:
Ashtar (Extraterrestrial Being) üîó

This entry focuses on Ashtar, an alleged extraterrestrial being or group of beings, primarily within the context of ufology and UFO religions. It notes the “unbalanced” tag, indicating a need for more diverse viewpoints.

Key points:

  • Ashtar is a name associated with an extraterrestrial being or group of beings.
  • Claims of contact are made through channeling.

Important People:

  • George Van Tassel

Locations:

  • United States

Major Events:

  • First claimed contact in 1952.

History üîó

This section details the background and development of the Ashtar concept, from its roots in Theosophy to its popularization through UFO contactees.

Key points:

  • Ascended Masters from esoteric teachings are described as reappearing in space suits.
  • The concept of Ascended Masters is clear in the Ashtar teachings.
  • The word “ashtar” appears in Helena Blavatsky’s The Secret Doctrine.

Important People:

  • Helena Blavatsky
  • George Van Tassel

Locations:

  • Giant Rock, California
  • Mojave Desert, California
  • Landers, California

Major Events:

  • Van Tassel moves to Giant Rock in 1947 and establishes a UFO Center.
  • The “Ministry of Universal Wisdom” is founded in 1953.

Purported contact with Van Tassel üîó

This section focuses on George Van Tassel’s claims of telepathic communication with Ashtar, including the apocalyptic messages he received and his interpretation of the Bible in terms of extraterrestrial intervention.

Key points:

  • Van Tassel claimed to receive messages from Ashtar in 1952.
  • Van Tassel interpreted the Bible in terms of extraterrestrial intervention.
  • Van Tassel claimed to receive instructions from Nikola Tesla to build the “Integratron”.
  • Early messages from Ashtar contained apocalyptic material regarding the hydrogen bomb.
  • Ashtar entered the Solar System as Commander in Chief of the Ashtar Galactic Command to warn humanity of the dangers of detonating the H-bomb.
  • Van Tassel claimed that Ashtar provided specific messages to pass on to the U.S. federal government.
  • Van Tassel claimed to have established a new form of telepathic communication with extraterrestrial intelligences.

Important People:

  • George Van Tassel
  • Nikola Tesla

Major Events:

  • Van Tassel’s first purported contact with Ashtar in 1952.
  • The claimed intervention of Ashtar to prevent Earth’s destruction through nuclear power.

Giant Rock Space Conventions üîó

This section describes the weekly channeling sessions and annual conventions held at Giant Rock, which helped to coalesce the contactee subculture.

Key points:

  • Van Tassel held weekly channeling sessions at Giant Rock.
  • These gatherings coalesced the scattered contactee subculture into a recognizable movement in January 1952.
  • The annual Giant Rock Spacecraft Convention began in 1953.
  • Most of the well-known UFO contactees attended these conventions as speakers and channelers.
  • Most of the early messages Van Tassel claimed to have received from Ashtar were first presented to the public at these events.

Important People:

  • George Van Tassel
  • J. Gordon Melton

Locations:

  • Giant Rock

Major Events:

  • The first Giant Rock Spacecraft Convention in 1953.

Ashtar Command üîó

This section details the appropriation of the “Ashtar Command” concept by other contactees and channelers, leading to conflicting messages and a lack of central authority.

Key points:

  • The concept of an “Ashtar Command” was appropriated for use by a number of prominent early contactees and channelers.
  • Robert Short began his own group called “Ashtar Command”.
  • By the mid-1950s, the concept of Ashtar and a galactic law enforcement agency preparing an imminent rescue of humanity had become well-established.
  • The public failure of predictions had a negative impact on the expansion of the Ashtar Command movement.
  • Dozens of Ashtar channelers were presenting conflicting messages.

Important People:

  • George Van Tassel
  • Robert Short
  • Elouise Moeller
  • Adelaide J. Brown

Locations:

  • Giant Rock

Development into spiritual religion (1990s onward) üîó

This section describes the evolution of the Ashtar message from a technological communication to a more spiritual role, with Ashtar becoming an Ascended Master figure.

Key points:

  • The Ashtar message evolved into a spiritual message.
  • Ashtar began to play more of an Ascended Master role in the narratives.
  • The Ashtar Command evolved into a movement that had a central authority for several decades up to the mid-1990s.
  • The teachings claiming to be channeled from Ashtar varied immensely.
  • Much of the Ashtar channeling is akin to cargo cults.
  • Most of the Ashtar millenarian concepts involve a transformation of human beings, via these technologies, who will then return to the planet Earth to enjoy a golden millennium.
  • With the failure of prophecies, teachings were modified to include a less material and more spiritual emphasis.

Important People:

  • Tuella
  • Andreas Grunschloss

1970s broadcasts üîó

This section mentions the 1977 Southern Television broadcast interruption, where a voice claiming to be “Vrillon” of the Ashtar Galactic Command took over a television transmitter.

Key points:

  • In 1971, a British radio talk show devoted to UFOs received a strange call-in claiming to originate from outer space.
  • In 1977, a voice calling itself “Vrillon” of the Ashtar Galactic Command temporarily took over a television transmitter in southern England.

Locations:

  • Southern England

Major Events:

  • The 1977 Southern Television broadcast interruption.

1986 prediction of 1994 apocalypse üîó

This section details Yvonne Cole’s predictions of Earth’s destruction and the arrival of alien cultures in 1994, which ultimately failed to occur.

Key points:

  • Yvonne Cole predicted the destruction of all Earth civilizations and the arrival on the planet of various alien cultures in 1994.
  • Cole claimed that governments were working with extraterrestrials to prepare for contact.
  • The landing would be broadcast through the global media and include a message from the Ashtar Command.
  • These prophecies furthered the continued fracturing and disappointment within the movement when they failed to occur.

Important People:

  • Yvonne Cole

Major Events:

  • The failed 1994 apocalypse prediction.

The 1994 Pioneer Voyage meditations üîó

This section describes the “lift-off experience” claimed by some Ashtar Command members in 1994, where they were placed aboard “ships of Light” circling the planet.

Key points:

  • A small group of Ashtar Command members claimed that an extraordinary event had taken place: “the lift-off experience”.
  • “The Galactic Fifth Fleet” had used “physical vibrational transfer” which involved the human consciousness (or, sometimes, the “etheric body”) being raised from the physical dimension and transferred to the “Light ships”.
  • A second event was predicted for December 1994 in which over 250 people participated and which was declared by the leadership to have “opened a portal to the AC (Ashtar Command) ships for ever”.
  • The purpose of the lift-off is for the ascension of the human race as a whole, to which individual ascension is a precursor and an aid.
  • The collective ascension is being aided by large electronic grids deployed around the planet by the guardian ships.

Major Events:

  • The 1994 Pioneer Voyage meditations.

Developments after the mid-1990s üîó

This section discusses the use of the Internet by channeling groups to unify the movement and establish a single “authoritative” source for Ashtar messages.

Key points:

  • Several channeling groups began to utilize the Internet in order to promulgate their beliefs and to attempt to unify the movement.
  • This cohesive response addressed the problem of conflicting, negative and failed prophecies.
  • Individual channelers espousing messages which differed and continued to focus on themes such as the destruction of Earth, conspiracies, extraterrestrial mass evacuations and general fear-mongering were declared invalid.
  • The new, more unified movement declared that in future no new channels would be accepted unless they operated on the “level of the soul”.
  • Channeled messages from Ashtar would be accepted as valid by the new orthodoxy if they complied with criteria consisting of a set of twelve guidelines which outlined what the movement stood for and how Ashtar would interact with society.
  • The new framework claimed that the millions of spaceships believed to be constantly in the vicinity of Earth would

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashtar_(extraterrestrial_being)

item.title: Extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis üîó

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as physical spacecraft occupied by intelligent extraterrestrial organisms or probes designed by them.

Usage of the Term üîó

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature back to the mid-1960s. Key figures mentioned include French ufologist Jacques Vall√©e, who used the term in his 1966 book, and French engineer Aim√© Michel, who used it in a 1967 publication. James E. McDonald and James Harder also used the term in 1968, including during testimony before a Congressional committee. Skeptic Philip J. Klass used it in his 1968 book. Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” after defining it in the Condon Report (1969).

Chronology üîó

This section explores the historical roots of the ETH, tracing it back to earlier concepts such as Percival Lowell’s ideas about Martian canals and civilizations, the science fiction writings of H. G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century and theorized about visitors from other worlds. The modern ETH took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience and popular culture, and bolstered by unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups like NICAP and APRO.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits üîó

This section provides historical examples of speculation about extraterrestrial visitors. It mentions a story from 1864 about the discovery of a mummified alien-like creature. It also discusses H. G. Wells’ “The War of the Worlds” (1898), which popularized the idea of Martian invasion, and the “mystery airships” of the late 19th century, which some speculated were from Mars. Comic strips, radio shows, and movie serials like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon also contributed to the idea of alien visitation. Orson Welles’ 1938 radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” caused public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America üîó

This section focuses on the surge of UFO sightings in 1947, beginning with Kenneth Arnold’s sighting of unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier. Arnold considered the possibility of extraterrestrial origins, and fan mail suggested the same. Senator Glen Taylor expressed a wish for the flying saucers to be spaceships from another planet to unify Earth. R. DeWitt Miller suggested they could be vehicles from Mars or other dimensions. The work of Charles Fort was also brought up. However, most people were unwilling to immediately conclude that the objects were extraterrestrial, and various other theories proliferated. A Gallup poll in August 1947 showed that most people either had no opinion or believed there was a mundane explanation.

Evolution of Public Opinion üîó

This section examines how public opinion regarding the ETH evolved. It mentions movies from the early 1950s depicting flying saucers and aliens. A 1951 poll reported that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen a man-made aircraft, while only a small percentage believed they had seen an alien craft. By 1957, 25% of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A 2002 Roper poll reported that 56% of respondents thought UFOs were real, with 48% believing that UFOs had visited Earth.

Religion üîó

This section briefly mentions the connection between UFOs and religion, citing the Aetherius Society, founded by George King in 1955, as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA üîó

This section discusses NASA’s involvement with UAPs. In June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon and explored the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP and presented a paper in August 2021 supporting ETH.

Private or Government Studies üîó

This section presents examples of private or government studies that have concluded in favor of the ETH or had members who disagreed with official conclusions. It mentions a 1948 USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins. It also discusses the USAF Project Sign’s Top Secret Estimate of the Situation (1948), which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation, but was ordered destroyed. A West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, also concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. The CIA started their own internal scientific review. Extraterrestrial “believers” within Project Blue Book included Major Dewey Fournet and director Edward J. Ruppelt. The first CIA Director, Vice Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, urged Congressional action to reduce secrecy about UFOs. In 1967, Greek physicist Paul Santorini claimed that a 1947 Greek government investigation concluded that the European Ghost rockets of 1946 were extraterrestrial. David Saunders disagreed with the negative conclusion of the 1968 Condon Report. The 1999 French COMETA report concluded that the extraterrestrial visitor hypothesis was the most likely explanation for UFO phenomena. Jean-Jacques Velasco, the head of the official French UFO investigation SEPRA, wrote that 14% of the cases studied were extraterrestrial in origin.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH üîó

This section presents critical responses to the ETH. It states that there is no scientific proof to back up assertions of alien presence on Earth. No rigorous analysis has ever concluded that UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery üîó

This section discusses the U.S. military’s involvement in investigating and debunking UFOs. Army Air Forces Intelligence began a secret study of saucer reports in July 1947. The U.S. Air Force’s Project Sign was formed at the end of 1947. In 1948, Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The CIA’s Office of Scientific Investigation took particular interest in UFOs after the 1952 UFO wave. The CIA organized the Robertson Panel in 1953, which recommended a policy of public debunkery to reduce UFO reports.

Involvement of Scientists üîó

This section discusses the scientific community’s lack of support for the ETH. Reports of UFOs are generally attributed to misinterpretations of common objects or phenomena, or hoaxes. Stephen Hawking expressed skepticism about the ETH. Carl Sagan noted the emotional nature of the idea of extraterrestrial visitation and the potential for self-deception. Peter A. Sturrock argued that the focus on the ETH has narrowed the debate. Sturrock conducted polls of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics and American Astronomical Society members, which showed limited support for the ETH. J. Allen Hynek outlined seven key reasons why he could not accept the ETH, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, the behavior of UFOs and their occupants, the isolation of the UFO phenomenon, the space unworthiness of UFOs, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology üîó

This section notes that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, which has called into question the claimed phenomenology of UFOs.

NASA üîó

This section states that NASA’s official standpoint is that the ETH lacks empirical evidence. David Morrison stated that no one has ever found a single artifact or any other convincing evidence for alien visits.

CIA üîó

This section mentions that the CIA organized the January 1953 Robertson Panel of scientists to debunk the data collected by the Air Force’s Project Blue Book.

Official White House Position üîó

This section discusses the White House’s official response to petitions asking the U.S. government to acknowledge alien visits and disclose any withholding of government interactions with extraterrestrial beings. The response stated that the U.S. government has no evidence that any life exists outside our planet or that an extraterrestrial presence has contacted or engaged any member of the human race.

Counter Critique of the Official Position: Conspiracy Theories üîó

This section introduces the concept of a conspiracy of silence or an official cover-up suppressing information about UFOs. In 1968, James Harder argued that significant evidence existed to prove UFOs but had been suppressed. A 1971 survey showed that more Americans believed the government was concealing information about UFOs than believed in the existence of UFOs or the ETH itself. Former NASA astronauts, such as Gordon Cooper and Brian O’Leary, have commented on the government’s alleged suppression of UFO sightings.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_UFO_hypothesis

item.title: The Roswell Incident (1980 book)
item.description:
The Roswell Incident (1980 book) üîó

The Roswell Incident is a 1980 book by Charles Berlitz and William Moore that popularized stories of unusual debris recovered in 1947 by personnel from the Roswell Army Air Field. The book is available at the Internet Archive.

Background üîó

This section provides context for the book by outlining the events of 1947 and the renewed interest in the Roswell incident in the late 1970s.

Events of 1947 üîó

This section details the initial reports surrounding the Roswell incident, including the Roswell Army Air Field’s press release about recovering a “flying disc” and its subsequent retraction, claiming the object was a weather balloon. It also mentions the broader context of the “flying disc craze” of 1947, sparked by Kenneth Arnold’s alleged sighting.

Roswell revisited üîó

This section explains how the Roswell story gained renewed attention in 1978 when retired lieutenant colonel Jesse Marcel claimed in an interview with ufologist Stanton Friedman that he believed the debris he retrieved was of extraterrestrial origin.

Authors üîó

This section provides background information on the authors of the book, Charles Berlitz and William Moore. It notes Berlitz’s previous success with The Bermuda Triangle, a book that popularized the mysteries surrounding that area. It also mentions their collaboration on The Philadelphia Experiment: Project Invisibility, which explored tales of a Navy invisibility experiment and government cover-ups.

Contents üîó

This section summarizes the book’s central argument: that an extraterrestrial craft crashed in the New Mexico desert while observing nuclear weapons activity, and the US government engaged in a cover-up. It highlights accounts of debris described as “nothing made on this earth” and mentions witnesses like Bill Brazel, Floyd Proctor, and Walt Whitman Jr. The section also notes that the book introduced the idea that the debris shown in photos with Marcel was substituted as part of a cover-up and that the press was not allowed to closely inspect the recovered material. The authors claimed to have interviewed over 90 witnesses, but only a fraction of their testimonies appear in the book. The incarceration of Mac Brazel is also mentioned as a form of witness intimidation. The section also points out that the book elevated Marcel’s narrative over that of Cavitt, whose description of the debris contradicted Marcel’s claims.

Alien bodies üîó

This section explains that The Roswell Incident was the first book to introduce stories of civil engineer Grady “Barney” Barnett and archaeology students encountering wreckage and “alien bodies” on the Plains of San Agustin, far from the initial debris field near Corona. It also notes that some accounts of the Roswell incident contain information from the Aztec, New Mexico, UFO incident, a hoaxed flying saucer crash.

Reception üîó

This section summarizes the critical reception of the book, noting that some critics deemed it “a collection of wild hearsay” and questioned the authenticity of the Majestic 12 documents, with some suspicion falling on Moore. It also mentions that the book did not achieve the commercial success its authors had hoped for.

Aftermath üîó

This section mentions that Moore claimed to have engaged in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Modern views üîó

This section references the modern understanding of the Roswell incident. It mentions the 1993 inquiry from US congressman Steven Schiff, which led to a General Accounting Office investigation and an Air Force report concluding that the recovered material was likely debris from Project Mogul, a military surveillance program using high-altitude balloons.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roswell_Incident_(1980_book)

item.title: UFO sightings in the United States
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in the United States üîó

This document presents a compilation of reported UFO sightings within the United States, organized chronologically. Each entry includes the date, city, state, a link to a main article if available, and a brief description of the event.

Table of Sightings üîó

This table details alleged UFO sightings in the United States, spanning from 1865 to 2023. Each entry includes the date, city, state, a link to a main article if available, and a brief description of the event.

  • September 1865, Cadotte Pass, Montana: Trapper James Lumley reported witnessing a craft crash, describing sulfur smells and hieroglyphics.
  • 1896‚Äì1897, Multiple Locations, Multiple States: Sightings of airship-like vehicles were reported across the United States during the Mystery Airship wave.
  • April 17, 1897, Aurora, Texas: Residents claimed an airship crashed, and the alien pilot was buried in the local cemetery.
  • February 24, 1942, Los Angeles, California: The “Battle of Los Angeles” involved an alleged enemy attack and anti-aircraft artillery barrage. Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox called it a “false alarm,” later attributed to “war nerves” and a weather balloon.
  • August 1945, Jornada del Muerto, New Mexico: Two boys reported seeing an “avocado-shaped” object crash, containing insect-like alien creatures, shortly after the first atomic bomb detonation.
  • June 21, 1947, Maury Island, Washington: An incident reported before the Kenneth Arnold sighting, involving an alleged encounter with “men in black.”
  • June 24, 1947, Mount Rainier, Washington: Kenneth Arnold reported seeing nine unusual objects flying in formation near Mount Rainier, describing them as bright, erratic, and fast.
  • July 1947, Roswell, New Mexico: The Roswell UFO Incident involved the recovery of materials near Roswell, sparking speculation about a crashed alien craft versus a top-secret research balloon.
  • January 7, 1948, Maysville, Kentucky: The Mantell Incident involved the death of Captain Thomas F. Mantell, a Kentucky Air National Guard pilot, while pursuing a UFO.
  • July 24, 1948, Montgomery, Alabama: The Chiles-Whitted UFO Encounter involved two commercial pilots reporting a near-collision with a torpedo-shaped object.
  • October 1, 1948, Fargo, North Dakota: The Gorman Dogfight involved a US Air Force pilot sighting and pursuing a UFO for 27 minutes.
  • May 11, 1950, McMinnville, Oregon: Paul and Evelyn Trent took the McMinnville UFO photographs on their farm.
  • May 29, 1950, Mount Vernon, Maryland: Captain Willis Sperry and crewmembers on an American Airlines DC-6 reported a “brilliant, diffused, bluish light.”
  • August 15, 1950, Great Falls, Montana: The Mariana UFO incident garnered national media attention during a period of high interest in UFOs and alien invasion.
  • August 25, 1951, Lubbock, Texas: The Lubbock Lights were a v-shaped formation of lights seen over the town.
  • May 24, 1952, Burbank, California: Orfeo Angelucci claimed to encounter flying saucers and friendly human-appearing pilots during his drives home from an aircraft plant.
  • July 13, 1952, Washington, D.C.: The 1952 Washington, D.C. UFO incident involved a series of unidentified flying object reports over the city.
  • September 12, 1952, Flatwoods, West Virginia: Six boys and a woman reported seeing a UFO landing and a bizarre-looking creature.
  • November 23, 1953, Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan: Felix Moncla, Jr., a US Air Force pilot, disappeared with 2nd Lt. Robert Wilson while pursuing a UFO over Lake Superior.
  • November 2, 1957, Levelland, Texas: The Levelland UFO case involved multiple witnesses reporting unusual aerial phenomena.
  • September 19, 1961, Lancaster, New Hampshire: Betty and Barney Hill claimed to have been abducted by extraterrestrials.
  • April 24, 1964, Socorro, New Mexico: Lonnie Zamora, a New Mexico police officer, reported a UFO close encounter.
  • September 3, 1965, Exeter, New Hampshire: The Exeter incident involved a large UFO sighting by a teenager and two police officers.
  • December 9, 1965, Kecksburg, Pennsylvania: The Kecksburg UFO incident involved a large fireball seen over multiple states and Canada.
  • 1969, Leary, Georgia: Jimmy Carter claimed to have seen a UFO.
  • October 11, 1973, Pascagoula, Mississippi: The Pascagoula Abduction involved Charles Hickson and Calvin Parker claiming to have been abducted by aliens.
  • January 12, 1975, North Bergen, New Jersey: An incident occurred near the Stonehenge apartment building in North Bergen, New Jersey.
  • November 5, 1975, Snowflake, Arizona: Travis Walton claimed to have been abducted by a UFO.
  • December 17, 1977, Council Bluffs, Iowa: Local residents reported seeing a reddish fireball and recovered molten metal.
  • August 27, 1979, Stephen, Minnesota: Deputy Sheriff Val Johnson’s patrol car was struck by a blinding ball of light.
  • December 29, 1980, Dayton, Texas: The Cash-Landrum Incident involved a reported UFO sighting and subsequent health issues for the witnesses.
  • November 11, 1987, Gulf Breeze, Florida: The Gulf Breeze UFO incident occurred.
  • March 8, 1994, Multiple Locations, Michigan: Over 100 witnesses reported seeing objects with colored lights across West Michigan.
  • March 13, 1997, Phoenix, Arizona: The Phoenix Lights involved a series of optical phenomena seen by thousands of people. Former Arizona governor Fife Symington admitted to seeing a delta-shaped craft.
  • January 5, 2000, Highland, Illinois: The “St. Clair Triangle” sighting involved multiple police officers and other witnesses reporting a massive, silent, triangular aircraft.
  • August 21, 2004, Chicago, Illinois: A triangular formation of reddish lights was seen by hundreds of witnesses.
  • November 7, 2006, Chicago, Illinois: Employees at Chicago O’Hare International Airport reported seeing a metallic, saucer-shaped craft.
  • January 5, 2009, Morristown, New Jersey: Unidentified red objects were seen over Morristown, later revealed to be a hoax by Joe Rudy and Chris Russo.
  • February 19, 2018, Desert, Arizona: Commercial pilots saw an unidentified object, later attributed to a “high-altitude research balloon.”
  • February 21, 2021, Clayton, New Mexico: A pilot reported seeing a long cylindrical object.
  • February 10, 2023, Deadhorse, Alaska: A high-altitude object was shot down over the Beaufort Sea.
  • February 12, 2023, Lake Huron, Michigan: An octagonal object was shot down over Lake Huron.

See Also üîó

References üîó

This section lists the sources cited within the article, providing links to external websites, news articles, and books that support the information presented.

item.title: Dover Demon
item.description:
Dover Demon üîó

The Dover Demon is a cryptid reportedly sighted in Dover, Massachusetts, in April 1977.

Sightings üîó

This section details the reported sightings of the Dover Demon in April 1977. William “Bill” Bartlett, John Baxter, and Abby Brabham, all teenagers at the time, independently reported seeing a strange creature. Bartlett described it as a 4-foot tall creature with glowing orange eyes, a watermelon-shaped head, and no nose or mouth, seen on Farm Street. Baxter reported a similar sighting on Miller Hill Road, and Brabham claimed to have seen the creature on Springdale Avenue the following night. The teenagers drew sketches of the creature, with Bartlett swearing to the accuracy of his drawing. The locations of the sightings formed a straight line over 2 miles. The sightings became public in May, drawing comparisons to the Kelly‚ÄìHopkinsville encounter. The Mutual UFO Network investigated the sightings, despite no UFOs being reported by the witnesses.

Possible explanations üîó

This section explores potential explanations for the Dover Demon sightings. One suggestion is that the creature was a foal or a moose calf. Skeptic Joe Nickell proposes that the creature was likely a snowy owl, citing its size, plumage, and the reflection of headlights in its eyes. He suggests that the “long spindly arms” could have been the owl’s partially opened wings. Police suggested the sightings were a school vacation hoax. Skeptic Ben Radford suggests the sightings were influenced by the release of Star Wars and Close Encounters of the Third Kind in 1977.

In popular culture üîó

This section outlines the Dover Demon’s appearances in popular culture. It was featured in a 2009 episode of the television series Lost Tapes on Animal Planet. The Dover Demon appears as a character in the comic book series Proof and The Perhapanauts, as well as in The Pound: Ghouls Night Out and Hack/Slash: Entry Wound. It also appears in the webcomic Gunnerkrigg Court. Additionally, an alien known as Dover Demon appears in the manga series Dandadan.

Notes üîó

This section contains a note that one proposed explanation of the Kelly‚ÄìHopkinsville encounter is a great horned owl.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dover_Demon

item.title: Test Tube Aliens
item.description:
Test Tube Aliens üîó

This article discusses the Test Tube Aliens toy line, detailing their story, features, and functionality.

Story üîó

The narrative behind Test Tube Aliens involves two factions of aliens: the “good” aliens from the dying planet Naratuko seeking a new home, and the “evil” aliens responsible for their planet’s destruction, pursuing them across the universe. The good aliens reverted to a pre-birth state to escape, sacrificing strength for intelligence. Later, the storyline was altered to reveal that all the original aliens were evil, with the “true good” aliens being the X series. The evil aliens aimed to contaminate water sources after being discarded. This was followed by the release of “Test Tube Aliens: Pure Evil,” featuring entirely evil aliens.

The toy itself üîó

The toy consists of a test tube containing a “chrysalis” which, when water is added, dissolves to reveal an infant alien. The alien’s “heartbeat” is indicated by flashing lights. The alien requires feeding with “Sloog” (a powder mixed with water) initially, then tap water. It needs 12 hours of light and 12 hours of darkness daily to remain “healthy,” with the toy indicating if water levels are incorrect. If not cared for properly, the alien will “die.” The toy also interacted with a now-defunct website where users could check the alien’s health and induce coma or panic modes. A picture of Kurion, a good alien, is included.

How it works üîó

The alien’s body contains Polyacrylamide, a polymer that expands when it absorbs water. “Sloog” contains a weak acid that slows this expansion. Electrodes on the alien’s antenna and head sense the acid and water level, determining the alien’s “health.” A light detector in the alien’s head responds to flashes from the Test Tube Aliens website (no longer active) and tracks light/dark exposure.

References üîó

This section lists the sources used in the article, including a Popular Mechanics blog post by Erik Sofge.

External links üîó

This section provides a link to an archived version of the official Test Tube Aliens website.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_Tube_Aliens

item.title: Alien visitation
item.description:
Alien Visitation üîó

This entry defines “Alien visitation” as the concept that intelligent extraterrestrial beings have visited Earth. It then lists several claimed forms of such visitations.

  • Key Point: The core idea is the actual physical presence of aliens on Earth.

Claimed Forms of Visitation üîó

This section details specific types of alleged alien encounters.

  • Alien Abduction: Refers to instances where individuals claim to have been kidnapped by aliens.
  • Ancient Astronaut: This involves the theory that aliens influenced major historical events.
  • Close Encounter: Describes situations where individuals observe alien vessels.
  • Contactee: Designates a person who claims to have been contacted by aliens.

See also üîó

This section provides links to related topics.

  • Visitation (disambiguation): Directs users to a disambiguation page for the term “Visitation,” which covers other meanings of the word.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_visitation
